Section Title: IMPORTANT INFORMATION ABOUT THIS OFFERING MEMORANDUM
Subsection Title: Stabilization IN CONNECTION WITH THIS OFFERING, BNP PARIBAS (THE "STABILIZING MANAGER") (OR PERSONS ACTING ON ITS BEHALF) MAY OVER-ALLOT NOTES OR EFFECT TRANSACTIONS WITH A VIEW TO SUPPORTING THE MARKET PRICE OF THE NOTES DURING THE STABILIZATION PERIOD AT A LEVEL OTHER THAN THAT WHICH MIGHT OTHERWISE PREVAIL. HOWEVER, NO ASSURANCE CAN BE GIVEN THAT THE STABILIZING MANAGER (OR PERSONS ACTING ON ITS BEHALF) WILL UNDERTAKE STABILIZATION ACTION. ANY STABILIZATION ACTION MAY BEGIN ON OR AFTER THE DATE ON WHICH ADEQUATE PUBLIC DISCLOSURE OF THE FINAL TERMS OF THIS OFFERING IS MADE AND, IF BEGUN, MAY CEASE AT ANY TIME, BUT IT MUST END NO LATER THAN THE EARLIER OF 30 CALENDAR DAYS AFTER THE ISSUE DATE AND 60 CALENDAR DAYS AFTER THE DATE OF THE ALLOTMENT OF THE NOTES. ANY STABILIZATION ACTION OR OVER-ALLOTMENT MUST BE CONDUCTED BY THE STABILIZING MANAGER (OR PERSONS ACTING ON ITS BEHALF) IN ACCORDANCE WITH ALL APPLICABLE LAWS AND RULES. FOR A DESCRIPTION OF THESE ACTIVITIES, SEE "PLAN OF DISTRIBUTION."

Section Title: IMPORTANT INFORMATION ABOUT THIS OFFERING MEMORANDUM
Subsection Title: Notice to Certain Investors United States
Subsubsection Text: In making your purchase, you will be deemed to have made certain acknowledgments, representations and agreements. See "Notice to Investors." This Offering Memorandum is being provided to investors (i) in the United States that the Issuer reasonably believes to be QIBs under Rule 144A for informational use solely in connection with their consideration of the purchase of the Notes and the Guarantees (the “Securities”) and (ii) outside the United States in offshore transactions in accordance with Regulation S. Its use for any other purpose in the United States is not authorized. It may not be copied or reproduced in whole or in part nor may it be distributed or any of its contents disclosed to anyone other than the prospective investors to whom it is originally submitted. Until 40 days after the commencement of this Offering, an offer or sale of the Securities within the United States by a dealer (whether or not participating in the Offering) may violate the registration requirements of the U.S. Securities Act if such offer or sale is made otherwise than in accordance with an available exemption from, or in a transaction not subject to, the registration requirements of the U.S. Securities Act. This Offering is being made in the United States in reliance upon exemptions from registration under the U.S. Securities Act for offers and sales of securities which do not involve a public offering, including Rule 144A under the U.S. Securities Act. Prospective investors are hereby notified that sellers of the Securities may be relying on the exemption from the registration requirements of Section 5 of the U.S. Securities Act provided by Rule 144A. The Securities may be offered and sold outside the United States in offshore transactions in reliance on Regulation S. Terms used in this paragraph have the meanings given to them by Regulation S. The Securities have not been registered with, recommended by or approved by the SEC, any state securities commission in the United States or any other securities commission or regulatory authority, nor has the SEC, any state securities commission in the United States or any such securities commission or authority passed upon the accuracy or adequacy of this Offering Memorandum. Any representation to the contrary is a criminal offense in the United States.

Section Title: IMPORTANT INFORMATION ABOUT THIS OFFERING MEMORANDUM
Subsubsection Title: MiFID II Product Governance / Professional Investors and ECPs (as defined below) Only Target Market:
Subsubsection Text: Solely for the purposes of each manufacturer's product approval process, the target market assessment in respect of the Notes has led to the conclusion that: (i) the target market for the Notes is eligible counterparties ("ECPs") and professional clients only, each as defined in Directive 2014/65/EU, as amended ("MiFID II"); and (ii) all channels for distribution of the Notes to ECPs and professional clients are appropriate. The target market and distribution channels may vary in relation to sales outside the EEA in light of local regulatory regimes in force in the relevant jurisdiction. Any person subsequently offering, selling or recommending the Notes (a "distributor") should take into consideration the manufacturers' target market assessment; however, a distributor subject to MiFID II is responsible for undertaking its own target market assessment in respect of the Notes (by either adopting or refining the manufacturers' target market assessment) and determining appropriate distribution channels. For the purposes of this paragraph, the term "manufacturers" shall mean such of the Initial Purchasers as are subject to the product governance rules under MiFID II.

Section Title: IMPORTANT INFORMATION ABOUT THIS OFFERING MEMORANDUM
Subsubsection Title: PRIIPS Regulation / Prohibition of Sales to EEA Retail Investors: The Notes are not intended to be offered,
Subsubsection Text: sold or otherwise made available to, and should not be offered, sold or otherwise made available to, any retail investor in the EEA. For these purposes, a "retail investor" means a person who is one (or more) of: (i) a retail client as defined in point (11) of Article 4(1) of MiFID II or (ii) a customer within the meaning of the Insurance Distribution Directive, where that customer would not qualify as a professional client as defined in point (10) of Article 4(1) of MiFID II. Consequently, no key information document required by Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014, as amended (the "PRIIPs Regulation"), for offering, selling or distributing the Notes or otherwise making them available to retail investors in the EEA has been prepared, and, therefore, offering, selling or distributing the Notes or otherwise making them available to any retail investor in the EEA may be unlawful under the PRIIPs Regulation. This Offering Memorandum has been prepared on the basis that any offer of the Notes in any member state of the EEA that is subject to the Regulation (EU) 2017/1129, as amended (the "EU Prospectus Regulation") will be made pursuant to an exemption under the EU Prospectus Regulation from the requirement to publish a prospectus for offers of the Notes. This Offering Memorandum is not a prospectus for the purposes of the EU Prospectus Regulation. Accordingly, any person making or intending to make an offer of the Notes in a member state of the EEA may only do so in circumstances in which no obligation arises for the Issuer or any of the Initial Purchasers to publish a prospectus pursuant to Article 3 of the EU Prospectus Regulation, in each case, in relation to such offer. Neither the Issuer nor the Initial Purchasers have authorized, nor do they authorize, the making of any offer of the Notes in circumstances in which an obligation arises for the Issuer or the Initial Purchasers to publish a prospectus for such offer.

Section Title: IMPORTANT INFORMATION ABOUT THIS OFFERING MEMORANDUM
Subsubsection Title: Prohibition of Sales to Retail Investors in Austria: The Offering is not a public offering in the Republic of
Subsubsection Text: Austria. The Notes may not be offered and sold in the Republic of Austria except in accordance with the provisions of the Austrian Capital Markets Act 2019 (Kapitalmarktgesetz 2019) (as amended, the "Austrian Capital Markets Act"), of the EU Prospectus Regulation (as defined below), and any other laws applicable in the Republic of Austria. This offering memorandum has not been and will not be submitted to, nor has it been nor will it be approved by, the Austrian Financial Markets Authority (Finanzmarktaufsichtsbehörde) ("FMA"). FMA has not obtained and will not obtain a notification from another competent authority of a Member State, with which a securities prospectus may have been filed, pursuant to Article 25 of the EU Prospectus Regulation (as defined below). The Notes must not be distributed within Austria by way of a public offer, public advertisement or in any similar manner, and this offering memorandum and any other document relating to the Notes, as well as information contained therein, may not be supplied to the public in Austria or used in connection with any offer for subscription of Notes to the public in Austria. Consequently, in Austria the Notes will only be available to, and this offering memorandum and any other offering material in relation to the Notes is directed only at, persons who are qualified investors (qualifizierte Anleger) within the meaning of Article 2 e) of the EU Prospectus Regulation (as ----- defined below). The Notes will not be offered, sold or otherwise made available to any retail investor in Austria. For the purpose of this clause, a "retail investor" means a person who is one (or more) of: (i) a retail client as defined in point (11) of Article 4(1) of Directive 2014/65/EU ("MiFID II"); or (ii) a customer within the meaning of Directive 2016/97/EU, where that customer would not qualify as a professional client as defined in point (10) of Article 4(1) of MiFID II. Any resale of the Notes in Austria may only be made in accordance with the Austrian Capital Markets Act, the EU Prospectus Regulation (as defined below) and other applicable laws.

Section Title: IMPORTANT INFORMATION ABOUT THIS OFFERING MEMORANDUM
Subsection Title: PRESENTATION OF FINANCIAL INFORMATION Historical Financial Data
Subsubsection Text: This Offering Memorandum includes the following consolidated financial statements of the Group: - the unaudited condensed consolidated interim financial statements, including the notes thereto, of the Group as of and for the six months ended June 30, 2023 (the "HY 2023 Interim **Financial Statements"); - the audited consolidated financial statements, including the notes thereto, of the Group as of and for the financial year ended December 31, 2022 (the "FY 2022 Financial Statements"); - the audited consolidated financial statements, including the notes thereto, of the Group as of and for the financial year ended December 31, 2021 (the "FY 2021 **Financial Statements"); and - the audited consolidated financial statements, including the notes thereto, of the Group as of and for the financial year ended December 31, 2020 (the "FY 2020 Financial Statements"). The FY 2022 Financial Statements, the FY 2021 Financial Statements and the FY 2020 Financial Statements are herein collectively referred to as the "Annual Financial Statements." The Annual Financial Statements, together with the HY 2023 Interim Financial Statements, are herein collectively referred to as the "Financial Statements" The HY 2023 Interim Financial Statements have been prepared in accordance with the requirements of International Accounting Standard 34 "Interim Financial Reporting" as adopted by the European Union ("IAS 34") and the accounting policies included in the FY 2022 Financial Statements. For further information, see note 2.1 to the HY 2023 Interim Financial Statements. The FY 2022 Financial Statements and the FY 2021 Financial Statements have been audited by Deloitte Accountants B.V., who issued unqualified opinions as part of the corresponding audit reports for each period. The FY 2022 Financial Statements have been prepared in accordance with international financial reporting standards as adopted by the European Union ("IFRS") and in accordance with Title 9, Book 2 of the Dutch Civil Code. The FY 2021 Financial Statements have been prepared in accordance with the statutory provisions of Part 9, Book 2, of the Dutch Civil Code and the firm pronouncements in the Guidelines for Annual Reporting in the Netherlands as issued by the Dutch Accounting Standards Board ("Dutch GAAP"). The FY 2020 Financial Statements have been audited by Baker Tilly (Netherlands) N.V., who issued an unqualified opinion, and have been prepared in accordance with Dutch GAAP. Our financial year runs from January 1 to December 31. The Financial Statements are contained in the F-pages to this Offering Memorandum and should be read in conjunction with the relevant notes thereto.

Section Title: IMPORTANT INFORMATION ABOUT THIS OFFERING MEMORANDUM
Subsection Title: PRESENTATION OF FINANCIAL INFORMATION Historical Financial Data
Subsubsection Text: We first prepared annual consolidated financial statements in accordance with IFRS for the year ended December 31, 2022. Until December 31, 2021, we prepared our consolidated financial statements in accordance with Dutch GAAP. Accordingly, we prepared the FY 2022 Financial Statements in compliance with IFRS as of and for the year ended December 31, 2022, together with the comparative period data as of and for the year ended December 31, 2021. In preparing the FY 2022 Financial Statements, our opening statement of financial position was prepared as of January 1, 2021, the date of our transition to IFRS. ----- As Dutch GAAP differs in significant respects from IFRS, the adoption of IFRS greatly reduces the comparability of the FY 2022 Financial Statements prepared under IFRS with the FY 2021 Financial Statements and FY 2020 Financial Statements prepared in accordance with Dutch GAAP. See "Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition _and Results of Operations—Certain Differences Between Dutch GAAP and IFRS." In order to aid in the understanding of_ our financial information on a comparable basis in this Offering Memorandum, we present our historical financial condition and results of operations as follows (unless otherwise indicated): - as of and for the six months ended June 30, 2023 (and comparative information for the six months ended June 30, 2022), as derived from the HY 2023 Interim Financial Statements prepared in accordance with IAS 34, the IFRS standard applicable to interim financial statements; - as of and for the year ended December 31, 2022, as derived from the FY 2022 Financial Statements prepared in accordance with IFRS; - as of and for the year ended December 31, 2021, as derived from the comparative financial information as of and for the year ended December 31, 2021 included in the FY 2022 Financial Statements prepared in accordance with IFRS; - as of and for the year ended December 31, 2020, as derived from (i) the opening statement of financial position as of January 1, 2021 included in note 30 to the FY 2022 Financial Statements prepared in accordance with IFRS and (ii) unaudited management financial information for the year ended December 31, 2020 presented using the principles applied by the Company to restate its Dutch GAAP financial statements in accordance with IFRS (the "Reconciled Financial Information"). The Reconciled Financial Information for the year ended December 31, 2020 has been prepared by management to aid in the understanding of our financial information on a more comparable basis with our financial information for subsequent periods prepared in accordance with IFRS. The adjustments to the FY 2020 Financial Statements prepared in accordance with Dutch GAAP to present the Reconciled Financial Information have been prepared on a basis that our management believes is consistent in all material respects as the basis on which our consolidated financial information is prepared in accordance with IFRS. See "Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of _Operations—Certain Differences Between Dutch GAAP and IFRS." However, the presentation of the Reconciled Financial_ Information is based on certain management assumptions and estimates, has been prepared for illustrative purposes only and, because of its nature, the Reconciled Financial Information addresses a hypothetical situation and, therefore, does not represent and may not give a true picture of our results for the year ended December 31, 2020 if we had prepared audited financial statements in accordance with IFRS for such period. For example, the Reconciled Financial Information has not retrospectively applied the IFRS requirements for business combinations as of January 1, 2020. The Reconciled Financial Information is unaudited, is not fully comparable with our financial information for subsequent periods and should not be regarded as a substitute for our FY 2020 Financial Statements prepared in accordance with Dutch GAAP. See also "Risk _Factors—Financial Risks—Our current financial statements are prepared in accordance with IFRS and are not comparable with our prior financial statements prepared in accordance with Dutch GAAP." For additional information_ and a management reconciliation of the Reconciled Financial Information for the year ended December 31, 2020 to the FY 2020 Financial Statements prepared under Dutch GAAP, see "Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial _Condition and Results of Operations—Certain Differences Between Dutch GAAP and IFRS."_ Prospective investors are advised to consult their professional advisors for an understanding of: (i) the differences between Dutch GAAP, IFRS and other generally accepted accounting principles and how those differences might affect the financial information included in this Offering Memorandum; and (ii) the impact that future additions to, or amendments of, IFRS may have on the financial information presented in this Offering Memorandum, our results of operations and/or financial condition, as well as on the comparability of prior periods. You should read this discussion in conjunction with the sections entitled "Summary—Summary Consolidated Financial and Other Information," "Risk Factors," "Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations" and the consolidated financial statements and the accompanying notes included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum.

Section Title: IMPORTANT INFORMATION ABOUT THIS OFFERING MEMORANDUM
Subsubsection Text: In our FY 2022 Financial Statements, FY 2021 Financial Statements and FY 2020 Financial Statements, we defined Net Debt as "Gross debt (representing long- and short-term borrowings and lease liabilities (excluding derivatives and financial guarantee contracts)) less cash and cash equivalents." For the financial year ending December 31, 2023, we reconsidered our definition of Net Debt and decided to no longer include amortized costs as part of Net Debt. Accordingly, in this Offering Memorandum, we define Net Debt as "Gross debt (representing long- and short-term borrowings (excluding amortized costs) and lease liabilities (excluding derivatives and financial guarantee contracts) less cash and cash equivalents." We believe the revised definition of Net Debt provides investors with more useful information and we intend to continue to present Net Debt in accordance with this revised definition going forward. We have applied our revised definition of Net Debt throughout this Offering Memorandum for each of the periods presented, and as a result, the amount of Net Debt presented herein does not reconcile to the amounts presented in the Annual Financial Statements.

Section Title: IMPORTANT INFORMATION ABOUT THIS OFFERING MEMORANDUM
Subsubsection Text: This Offering Memorandum contains certain financial measures and ratios, including Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA Margin, Capital Expenditure (excluding acquisitions), Cash Conversion, Free Cash Flow, Gross Capital Expenditure, Gross Debt, Net Debt, Net Debt/Adjusted EBITDA, Operating Cash Flow, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA, Reported EBITDA, Reported EBITDA Margin and Reported Free Cash Flow, that are not required by, or presented in accordance with, IFRS (the "Non-IFRS Measures"). For reconciliations of the Non-IFRS Measures to the nearest IFRS measures, see "Summary—Summary Consolidated Financial and Other Information" and "Management's Discussion and _Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Capital Expenditures," "—Free Cash Flow," and "—Net Debt."_ ----- The Non-IFRS Measures are used by our management to assess operating performance, and we believe that they and similar measures are widely used in our industry as a means of evaluating a company's operating performance and financing structure, and because we believe they present helpful comparisons of financial performance between periods by excluding the distorting effect of certain non-recurring items. These measures may not be comparable to other similarly titled measures of other companies and are not measurements under IFRS standards or other generally accepted accounting principles. The Non-IFRS Measures are not measurements of our performance or liquidity under IFRS and should not be considered as alternatives to operating profit or profit from ordinary operations or any other performance measures derived in accordance with IFRS or as alternatives to cash flow from operating, investing or financing activities. The Non-IFRS Measures include figures derived from the HY 2023 Interim Financial Statements, the Annual Financial Statements and accounting records through aggregation, subtraction or division, but the Non-IFRS Measures have neither been audited nor reviewed. We define these Non-IFRS Measures as follows: - **_Adjusted EBITDA_** represents our Reported EBITDA, adjusted for certain one-off items described in "Summary Consolidated Financial and Other Information—Summary Non-IFRS Measures and As _Adjusted Financial Information";_ - **_Adjusted EBITDA Margin represents Adjusted EBITDA divided by revenue, expressed as a percentage; - **_Capital Expenditure (excluding acquisitions)_** represents purchases of property, plant and equipment plus purchases of intangible assets shown on our consolidated statement of cash flows; - **_Cash Conversion represents Operating Cash Flow divided by Reported EBITDA; - **_Free Cash Flow represents_** our Operating Cash Flow less Capital Expenditure (excluding acquisitions) and the carrying amount of sold property, plant and equipment; - **_Gross Capital Expenditure represents our Capital Expenditure (excluding acquisitions) plus acquisitions shown on our consolidated statement of cash flows; - **_Gross Debt_** represents our long- and short-term borrowings (excluding amortized costs) and lease liabilities (excluding derivatives and financial guarantee contracts), see also "—Net Debt" below; - **_Net Debt represents our Gross Debt less cash and cash equivalents, see also "—Net Debt" below; - **_Net Debt/Adjusted EBITDA represents Net Debt divided by Adjusted EBITDA; - **_Operating Cash Flow represents_** our Reported EBITDA adjusted for changes in net working capital and operating lease payments; - **_Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA represents our Adjusted EBITDA, after giving pro forma effect to the expected EBITDA impact of completed acquisitions in the first six months of 2023 described in "Summary Consolidated Financial and Other Information—Summary Non-IFRS Measures and As _Adjusted Financial Information";_ - **_Reported EBITDA represents profit for the year/period before depreciation and amortization expense, financial income, financial expense, share of profit of joint venture, income tax expense and other operating expenses. Other operating expenses represents the impairment of our investment in Fortrent in the year ended December 31, 2022; - **_Reported EBITDA Margin represents Reported EBITDA divided by revenue, expressed as a percentage; and - **_Reported Free Cash Flow represents_** our Reported EBITDA adjusted for the carrying amount of sold property, plant and equipment, less Capital Expenditure (excluding acquisitions). These Non-IFRS Measures may be defined differently from the corresponding terms under the Indenture and have limitations as analytical tools, and you should not consider them in isolation. Some of their limitations are the following: - they do not reflect our cash expenditures or future requirements for capital investments or contractual commitments; - they do not reflect changes in, or cash requirements for, our working capital needs; ----- - they do not reflect the significant interest expense, or the cash requirements necessary, to service interest or principal payments on our debt; - they do not reflect any cash income taxes that we may be required to pay; - although depreciation and amortization are non-cash charges, the assets being depreciated and amortized will often need to be replaced in the future and the relevant Non-IFRS Measures do not reflect any cash requirements that would be required to make such replacements; - they do not reflect the impact of certain cash charges resulting from matters we consider not to be indicative of our ongoing operations; and - other companies in our industry may calculate these measures differently from the way we do, limiting their usefulness as comparative measures. Because of these limitations, these Non-IFRS Measures should not be considered as measures of discretionary cash available to us to invest in the growth of our business or as measures of cash that will be available to us to meet our obligations. You should compensate for these limitations by relying primarily on our audited financial information and by using these Non-IFRS Measures only to supplement your evaluation of our performance.

We are a leading rental equipment specialist in Europe. We believe we are the second largest equipment rental company in Europe based on revenue for 2022, with strong market positions across our main markets, including the largest market share in each of the Netherlands, Belgium and Sweden and the second largest market share in each of Germany and Finland, in each case in terms of revenue in 2022. Our family-owned business started out of four garage boxes in the 1970s, and, under five decades later, has expanded into an industry leader with an extensive network of 759 depots in 18 European countries and a fleet of approximately 860,000 rental units as at June 30, 2023. In the twelve months ended June 30, 2023, we generated €1,524.9 million in revenue and €540.2 million in Adjusted EBITDA. We serve customers in a variety of end-markets from civil engineering, industrial, construction and infrastructure to events and warehousing. Our core product offering includes general and specialist rental equipment alongside complementary products and services, enabling us to be a one-stop-shop for our customer base of both corporate clients (business-to-business) and individuals including craftsmen and retail clients (business-to-consumer). Our generalist division is mainly focused on the less cyclical 'fit-out, maintain and operate' market segments which use lighter equipment, while our specialist division is tailored to reach niche markets, such as site preparation, sanitation and access control. With approximately 860,000 rental items, with a purchase value of €2.8 billion as of June 30, 2023, we offer our customers access to one of the largest, widest, highest quality, and latest ranges of rental equipment and tools in Europe, for use in the fields of civil engineering (such as excavators, landscaping tools and dumpers), transport and handling (such as forklifts, cranes and trailers), climate control (such as heating and cooling systems, mobile boilers and air purifiers), and construction (such as construction site and installation products), among others. In addition to our vast range of tools and equipment available in our general depots, we provide a wide range of specialist products to niche markets primarily outside the construction industry, which we believe differentiates us from our competition and contributes to our strong brand recognition and greater diversification in terms of end-markets and product offering. Our specialist products range from HVAC systems and hoisting and lifting machines to mobile LED screens, temporary housing solutions, portable kitchens and heavy duty pumps. In parallel, we offer "do-it-yourself" ("DIY") shop-in-shops across Europe, in partnership with DIY retailers where retail clients get access to primarily smaller equipment rental, which we believe further renders our business less cyclical than the traditional equipment rental business. Our corresponding service lines are geared towards further simplifying our customers' complex projects and include equipment service and maintenance, fuel management, training courses, project management and emergency assistance. In this Offering Memorandum, we present certain information for the following four geographic regions: - **_The Netherlands, which generated €362.9 million in revenue (representing 23.8% of our revenue) in the twelve months ended June 30, 2023; - **_Central Europe, consisting of Belgium, Germany, Austria, Hungary, Switzerland, Luxembourg, Poland, the Czech Republic and Slovakia, which generated €538.9 million in revenue (representing 35.3% of our revenue) in the twelve months ended June 30, 2023; - **_Northern Europe, consisting of Sweden, Norway, Finland, Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania, which generated €576.8 million in revenue (representing 37.8% of our revenue) in the twelve months ended June 30, 2023; and - **_Other Countries, consisting of Italy and the United Kingdom, which generated €46.4 million in revenue (representing 3.0% of our revenue) in the twelve months ended June 30, 2023. In addition, in the six months ended June 30, 2023, we introduced segmental reporting in line with IFRS 8 "Operating Segments" for the first time. For additional information on our operating segments, see "Presentation of _Financial Information—Operating Segments."_ ----- We operate under two main brands: Boels Rental and Cramo. Boels Rental, the original brand of the Boels Group, is active in 12 countries in Central and Western Europe and we believe holds the strongest brand recognition across our portfolio. Cramo is active in the Nordic and the Baltic states, having been an independent leading rental company in Europe since 1953 before we acquired it in 2020. We operate a hub-and-spoke depot network, consisting of 681 general rental product depots and 78 specialist rental product depots as of June 30, 2023. We believe the decentralized structure of our network enables us to provide our products and services to our customers more conveniently and efficiently, while also supplying us with a diversified and local customer reach. In countries where we have an extensive depot network, such as the Netherlands and Germany, each depot is connected to a central hub location. In countries with larger markets, we have several hubs. Our depots generally stock smaller and more commonly used equipment, while the larger and less commonly used equipment is stored at our hubs, from where they can be easily shipped directly to a customer or local depot as needed. We believe this structure allows us to make more efficient use of our fleet and minimize transport movements. Through a combination of organic growth and strategic acquisitions, we have expanded significantly over the past decade, both in terms of geographical reach and product offering. Since Pierre Boels Jr. became the CEO of Boels in 1996, we have executed a growth strategy based on product portfolio diversification and greenfield openings (including through international expansion), as well as through strategic bolt-on acquisitions executed to enter specific geographic areas (such as Germany, the UK and the Nordics) or specialist markets (such as industrial rental and traffic service). In 2020, we acquired Cramo, which positioned us as one of the largest equipment rental companies in Europe and complemented our geographic presence with an expansion into the Nordics and a further extension of our Central European offering. In addition, our 2022 acquisition of Eekels Pompen allowed us to expand our specialist product line by adding a high-quality offering of pump rentals to our customers with niche needs. The sharing economy is at the very heart of our business, and we believe that long-term growth prospects for the equipment rental industry continue to be favorable, driven by increased consumer preferences for rental instead of ownership. From our perspective, renting provides our customers with optimal availability, accessibility, and capital deployment, enabling them to reduce the amount of capital required for their operations, and, in turn, increase their capacity to deploy it for other investments. As such, our rental concept aims to help customers and their end-consumers meet their targets in terms of costs, efficiency, quality and sustainability. We also believe that rental, compared to ownership, can contribute positively to the environment. Therefore, alongside the benefits that we strive to offer our customers, we also invest in products and solutions that align with our commitment to advancing sustainability in our and our customers' industries.

Subsubsection Title: Leading market positions in a large and growing European market supported by favorable underlying growth drivers
Subsubsection Text: We have grown significantly since our founding in 1977 as a local rental company. Since then, we have grown into a multinational company through a combination of organic growth and transformative and bolt-on acquisitions. With the Cramo acquisition in 2020, which allowed us to expand our operations in the Nordics and Baltics while strengthening our network in Western and Central Europe, we have created a true pan-European rental equipment player with increased scale and resilience. We believe that our current footprint provides us with beneficial scale in strong and growing geographic and customer end-markets. We believe we are the second largest equipment rental business in Europe by rental revenue in 2022. As of June 30, 2023, we operate a comprehensive depot network of 759 depots, comprising 681 general rental depots and 78 specialist rental depots. We believe that our scale is particularly important as a provider of rental equipment, because it helps us optimize fleet utilization rates through our ability to easily relocate units to areas with higher demand for specific types of equipment and provides us with additional bargaining power in negotiations with OEMs and equipment suppliers and maintenance partners. We believe that our scale and our market leadership also help to increase our brand recognition and affords us with greater opportunities to attract and retain talented and experienced personnel. In the Netherlands, which is historically our cornerstone market, we believe that we hold a strong leader position with between 25% and 30% of market share based on revenue in 2022, which we believe is significantly ahead of our competitors. We believe we are also the leader in Belgium with approximately 10% of market share and the second-largest player in Germany with between 5% and 10% of market share, in each case based on revenue in 2022. With the acquisition of Cramo in 2020, we expanded our presence into five more European markets (Sweden, Norway, Finland, Estonia and Lithuania) and significantly strengthened our position in six European countries where Boels and Cramo had a joint presence. We believe that we are the second largest player in Sweden, with close to 20% of market share, and in Finland, with more than 15% of market share, in each case based on revenue in 2022. ----- We believe that the markets we address are strong and poised for further growth. According to the ERA 2022 Market Report, the total market size of the top 15 European rental equipment markets is estimated to have increased by 4% from €24.7 billion in 2021 to €25.7 billion in 2022, and is forecasted to grow by 3.3% in 2023 and 5.6% in 2024. According to the ERA 2022 Market Report, the European market is expected to remain strong, driven by an increased rental penetration and a structural shift in customers' preferences towards renting rather than owning equipment. This shift is supported by the attractiveness and flexibility offered by renting, as it optimizes the split between operating costs and capital expenditures by reducing the fixed portion of maintenance and fleet replacement costs and allows customers to avoid investing in expensive equipment that may not be used frequently. Moreover, the transition to achieving net zero CO2 emissions amplifies this effect, as electric equipment is generally more expensive. This structural shift is expected to support continued demand for rental equipment companies' products and services over the medium and long term. We believe that we are well-positioned to benefit from growth and positive trends in the equipment rental industry. The European rental equipment industry is still highly fragmented, consisting of a large number of small companies serving local or regional markets, with a limited number of medium to larger companies serving regional, national and international customers. We believe we are one of only a few companies with a strong pan-European platform, with strong relationships with the key equipment OEMs. We compete with a large number of smaller competitors locally and a few larger international competitors. We believe that we are well-positioned for growth by leveraging our scale and footprint, while relying on our proven approach of customizing our strategy for each local market, while centralizing our key operations.

Subsubsection Title: Resilient business model supported by robust diversification across geographies, end markets, products and customers, supported by a notable depot network
Subsubsection Text: We strive to minimize the impact of economic cycles through continually maximizing our rental fleet utilization rate, developing specialist activities focused on non-construction related niche markets, diversifying our customer base by investing in a broad product range aimed at non-construction related customers and focusing on the less cyclical phases of construction projects. We have a diversified footprint and address several different customer end-markets, helping to mitigate our exposure to macroeconomic uncertainty. In particular, with the acquisition of Cramo, we significantly increased our geographical diversification, bringing our revenue generated in the Netherlands to 24% of our total revenue for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023, compared to nearly half of our total revenue for the year ended December 31, 2018. Moreover, no single country represented more than 25% of our revenue generation for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023. We believe that this enhanced geographic diversification gives us greater resilience during periods of slow economic growth, as different countries operate within different economic cycles. Based on our revenue and EBITDA growth, we believe we outperformed our largest European competitors during the COVID-19 pandemic, proving the resilience of our business model. The chart below provides a breakdown of our revenue by geographic segment for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023. We address multiple customer end markets, which also contributes to our resilience in reducing the impact of volatility of external factors such as market conditions and macroeconomic developments. We have positioned ourselves as a leading generalist equipment rental company that is also active in the attractive specialist sub-segment and in DIY, with specialist rental and DIY representing 28% of our revenue for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023. For the year ended December 31, 2022, approximately 54% of our sales were derived from non-construction end-markets, indicating a relatively modest exposure to the cyclical construction market. Furthermore, our exposure to the construction end market includes a large part of less cyclical phases of construction activities, such as the fit out, maintenance and operational phases. The chart below provides a breakdown of our revenue by end markets for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023. ----- Over time, we have continued developing our expertise in specialist rental equipment, focusing on nonconstruction related end-markets, such as site preparation, modular space, measurement, testing and safety, sanitation, portable kitchen, hoisting and lifting, access control, and industrial rental and pumps. We believe our specialized knowledge is key to our ability to service different niche markets, providing further resilience and less exposure to the more cyclical construction market. By leveraging our generalist rental equipment business, we also aim to provide the best and most comprehensive rental solutions for our customers with the objective of cross-selling our specialist equipment to fuel future growth. Ultimately, our specialist business represents a key peer differentiator with customers, which we believe provides for higher returns. In parallel, we also operate in the niche market of DIY rental, with more than 3,100 DIY shop-in-shops as at June 30, 2023, where customers at DIY retail stores have access to primarily smaller equipment rental such as tools. This type of business is less cyclical than traditional equipment rental market and the costs to operate this business are typically lower than other equipment rental businesses due to the strong operational leverage of the existing rental depot network. In the DIY market, we are able to offer convenience as a differentiating factor to our customers, generating higher customer foot traffic in the stores, at a time when e-commerce is putting a strain on retailers and brick-and-mortar stores. We strive to offer a wide range of equipment and tools across all the phases of construction projects, including the build (both heavy construction and fit out), operate and maintain phases. Our business model also hinges on providing a diversified range of products to our customers. We particularly focus on smaller equipment rentals, such as perforators, ladders, scaffolding, power saws, power generators, sanding equipment, which represented approximately 48% of our rental revenue for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023. These rentals position us within the less-cyclical 'fit out', 'maintain' and 'operate' phases of the asset cycle, as demand for such rentals is typically more resilient and makes us less dependent on lengthy construction projects. For example, smaller equipment rentals tend to be more sought after for renovation and maintenance use, which are inherently less exposed to cyclical demand than other end uses. As of June 30, 2023, with a fleet of approximately 860,000 equipment units, ranging from providing generalist tools to more specialized equipment, in addition to value-added services such as logistics, we aim to provide full turnkey solutions to strengthen our customer relationships and remain our customers' preferred rental partner. Furthermore, with a comprehensive network of 759 depots (strategically located within a 50-kilometer reach of our key customers and project sites across Europe) and more than 3,100 DIY shop-in-shops across Europe as of June 30, 2023, we are capable of mobilizing our rental fleet even in remote places for any customer or user at the right time, through multiple delivery methods: pick up and return or delivery to desired locations. By constantly adapting our network to changes and fluctuations in the market, we have the strategic ability to open or close access points near our customers. Based on market trends or developments in specific regions in Europe, we can adapt swiftly and embrace changes in our industry. Our hub-and-spoke networking model provides a diversified customer reach and develops efficiency and flexibility in our operations, ensuring that we are close to our customers and their projects, whether for pick-up and return or project delivery. This proximity to our customers results in shorter transport times, lower costs and lower CO2 emissions. Supported by our broad product offering and dense network, we also benefit from a large and diversified customer base, serving numerous customers of different sizes and from different sectors through our various channels (both generalist and specialist rental products) ranging from DIY customers, cash customers and craftsmen to large industrial, services and construction companies, potentially operating in different economic cycles. For the year ended December 31, 2022, our top 10 customers accounted for 7.4% of our revenue, with no single customer representing more than 2% of our revenue. We benefit from strong customer loyalty, evidenced by the fact that our 10 largest customers by revenue have, on average, an approximately 20-year relationship with us. -----

Subsubsection Title: Well-invested fleet focused on smaller equipment with strong unit economics and robust fleet management and digital capabilities
Subsubsection Text: We differentiate our offering from most of our peers by focusing on smaller rental items, such as tools and access equipment, in addition to construction equipment and containers. The chart below shows our revenue breakdown by product category for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023. Over the last five years, we have invested more than €1.4 billion to renew our rental fleet, with €448 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. We have a young, well-invested fleet with a historical purchase value of approximately €2.8 billion as of June 30, 2023. These investments have reduced the weighted average age of our fleet to 53 months as of June 30, 2023, allowing us to offer our customers the latest advanced equipment and sufficient headroom to reduce or delay our capital expenditures during economic downturns. The chart below shows our rental equipment fleet's average useful life and its age (in months), by product category, as of June 30, 2023. Our tools product category, which amounted to 16% of our rental sales for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023, has the lowest spread between average useful life and average fleet age in our fleet, with an average of approximately 3.5 years of use remaining before ultimately needing to be replaced. Our smaller equipment, such as perforators, ladders, scaffolding, power saws, power generators, sanding equipment, and other small tools, are characterized by superior unit economics compared to our other product categories, as they lead to higher money utilization rates (defined as our twelve-month fleet sales divided by the historical purchase price, based on the weighted average price by number of rental units). For the year ended December 31, 2022, our money utilization rate for the tools and light equipment product category was higher than our larger product categories, such as construction equipment, which we believe results in an increase in our return on fleet investments and an increase in our resilience through business cycles, given our high exposure to the tools and light equipment category. The chart below shows our money utilization rate for our different types of rental equipment for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023. ----- Our focus on tools and access equipment makes us less dependent on lengthy construction projects and more exposed to the less cyclical renovation market, where we have a better pricing power among our smaller customers. On our major long-term projects, we often provide a full range of equipment from small hand-held tools to larger equipment, reflecting our ability to support our clients on their various steps and needs with adequate and available equipment. This ability to provide full range of equipment in due time ultimately fosters relationships with our clients, creating recurring revenue streams and the potential for cross-selling between our generalist and specialist equipment. We have developed a robust asset management strategy for our extensive fleet. Our fleet management strategy covers the entire lifecycle of our equipment units, which includes purchasing, renting, and equipment servicing, as well as reselling the equipment at the end of its financial or economic lifetime. When making purchasing decisions, we seek to provide a true one-stop shop experience for our customers by ensuring a high degree of availability across our entire rental range and equipment that is adapted to their needs. By closely monitoring trends, events and market prices, we can quickly adjust and adapt our offer to customers' needs. For example, the share of Eco-labelled equipment in our fleet is relatively high and growing in line with higher market demand for electrical, hybrid or battery-powered equipment and the highest sustainability standards. Simultaneously, we seek time- and cost-efficiency to maximize our economies of scale and fleet occupancy performance. These initiatives improve our fleet availability and utilization rates while minimizing our maintenance capital expenditures. We have implemented an advanced and integrated infrastructure to drive decision making for our fleet, such as enterprise resource planning and specialized hardware and software. This asset management system allows us to track the complete life cycle of any rental asset in our fleet, providing us with visibility on our any given item (such as depot performance, inventory levels, fleet allocation and pricing) and the ability to adjust our fleet investment and pricing. This enables us able to serve our customers according to their needs, quickly and efficiently. In addition, this system makes it possible to limit downtime and improve utilization rates and pricing. Finally, as a piece of our equipment reaches the end of its lifecycle within the Company, we believe that we are able to optimize the timing of its resale and maximize its resale value through closely following secondary market prices and trends and taking third-party insights into account. Our fleet management strategy also relies on a central procurement strategy. This enables us to benefit from economies of scale and allows us to be close to our OEMs and their product development, positioning us at the forefront for the latest products in terms of efficiency, safety and sustainability. In addition, our relationships with OEMs not only allows us to negotiate better prices, but it also give us insights on the availability issues that may occur due to shortages of materials. In 2022, the equipment markets suffered from supply chain shortages. Due to our excellent relationships with our OEMs, we were able to successfully navigate these shortages, which we believe differentiates us from our competitors. We also foster our relationships with our OEMs by collaborating on technological developments and data analyses, and we aim to deepen our cooperation with them further. In addition, we have invested and continue to invest in the latest technology to help us efficiently process our fleet maintenance and repairs and minimize our related costs and administrative workload. These technological capabilities allow us to be in full control of depreciation and replacement strategies and therefore systematically improve our fleet usage, composition and performance. We monitor and reduce the impact machine repairs and maintenance have on lifetime costs and resale value. Finally, we seek to be a leader in innovation and digital transformation across the entire rental process, which we believe results in higher customer satisfaction and percentage of recurring business, better fleet damage control and substantial emissions savings. We were an early adopter of digital offerings in the European rental market, having anticipated this trend by preparing a detailed mapping of our customer experiences per segment, with the aim to simplify online rental in all our customer's life cycle stages and provide a one-stop-shop solution: from becoming a customer to online renting, logistics, usage, having all relevant information available and invoicing. In parallel, this digital transformation generates operational efficiencies by allowing us to optimize our processes such as transport and logistics. -----

Subsubsection Title: Strong financial and operational track record supported by counter-cyclical cash generation through capital expenditure flexibility and proven M&A integration capabilities
Subsubsection Text: Our financial performance has been driven by a strategic combination of strong organic growth and the successful integration of both transformative and smaller bolt-on acquisitions, which have expanded our geographical reach and product offering. Since our foundation more than 45 years ago, we have been focused on increasing scale and achieving sales growth. Our business model is based on actively distributing our fleet through our depot network, directly competing with local players and ultimately winning market share by providing newer equipment and better customer service. This model has delivered a proven track record of strong growth over the past decade. Between 2012 and 2022, our revenue grew at a CAGR of approximately 19%, significantly exceeding the growth of the economy, the construction market and the equipment rental market over the same period in Europe. While delivering robust sales growth, we have also managed to retain steady and high margins, with an Adjusted EBITDA margin of 35% in the twelve months ended June 30, 2023. By being highly focused on maintaining a high portion of variable costs, we have managed to retain our profitability during economic downturns. The following chart shows our revenue and Adjusted EBITDA growth from the year ended 2012 through the twelve months ended June 30, 2023.
We believe our success is attributable to the following competitive strengths which will drive our future growth:

Subsection Title: Long-term financial track record (€ millions and %)
Subsubsection Text: Notes: Figures between 2012 and 2019 reflect our reported results prepared in accordance with Dutch GAAP and are not comparable with subsequent periods prepared in accordance with IFRS. Figures provided for 2020 reflect the Reconciled Financial Information together with certain pro forma adjustments to reflect the acquisition of Cramo as if it had occurred on January 1, 2020. Figures provided for 2021, 2022 and the last twelve months ended June 30, 2023 reflect our results prepared in accordance with IFRS. It should be noted that the pro forma figures presented for 2020 represent a simple aggregation of relevant financial information of the Group and Cramo. Such information does not reflect any accounting or pro forma adjustments that may be required to present consolidated financial information and is presented for illustrative purposes only. The information and adjustments presented are based upon available information, management estimates and assumptions that are subject to inherent uncertainties, risks and change. See "Risk Factors—Financial Risks—We present information relating to Adjusted _EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA and other non-IFRS measures in this Offering Memorandum; certain of the data used in calculating this information was unaudited or involved certain estimates and judgments, and accordingly you should not unduly rely on them."_ (1) For comparability purposes, revenue growth between 2019 and 2020 is expressed as 2020 revenue pro forma to reflect the acquisition of Cramo as if it had occurred on January 1, 2020, compared to 2019 revenue pro forma to reflect the acquisition of Cramo as if it had occurred on January 1, 2019, each prepared under Dutch GAAP. Revenue for 2019 has been prepared solely for illustrative purposes based on management estimates utilizing a simple aggregation of the revenue of Cramo and our revenue for the year ended December 31, 2019. We have the ability to actively manage our fleet investment based on existing market conditions and the stage of the industry cycle, which has contributed to our counter-cyclical cash generation. In an industry growth cycle, we invest in our rental fleet to enhance our product catalogue and expand into new products and markets. In a downturn, with our newly invested young fleet, we can rapidly reduce our capital expenditures and postpone our investments, streamline our depot network and the size of the fleet, and pay down debt with our strong cash flows resulting from lower capital expenditures. Our business has flexibility to make investment decisions on a regular, short-term basis, and has no long-term expansionary capital expenditures commitments. Therefore, we are generally able to quickly adjust our fleet investments to respond to the changing market environment. For example, recently, we were able to quickly adapt our investments in response to the COVID-19 pandemic, focusing on maintaining our existing fleet through reduced capital expenditures. After the stabilization of market conditions in 2021, we resumed our investments by increasing our capital expenditures. ----- The countercyclical nature of cash generation and our ability to adjust our capital expenditure while preserving our cash generation through the cycles supports our conservative leverage policy and enables us to deleverage during challenging economic periods, as we did during the global financial crisis between 2008 and 2009, the double dip recession, and more recently, during the COVID-19 pandemic.

Subsubsection Title: Strong senior and local management teams with extensive industry experience
Subsubsection Text: We have a strong management team with extensive experience in the equipment rental industry and a track record of operational excellence, led by one of the most recognized and distinguished people in the industry, Pierre Boels Jr., our Chief Executive Officer since 1996 and President of the ERA between 2016 and 2022. The members of our management are further supported by divisional and regional managers in an organizational structure that empowers entrepreneurship spirit and decision making. Jan Piet Valk, our Chief Financial Officer since 2020 and member of our Management Board, has acquired a proven international experience through his previous chief financial officer positions. He is responsible for the overall financial management, M&A strategy, health and safety policy, legal, treasury, sustainability and real estate matters and is involved in all key decisions in the company. Mr. Valk has recently been awarded "CFO of the Year" by Financieel Management, in recognition of his independent role in the leadership of our Group, his management skills and his board position. Under Mr. Pierre Boels Jr.'s leadership, we managed to significantly increase our sales and EBITDA, both organically and through acquisitions, having successfully executed and integrated 27 acquisitions since 2012. Our CEO has assembled an experienced management team with significant industry expertise, including: - Reiant Mulder, Chief Operations Officer of Central Europe and member of our Strategic Board with more than 20 years of services experience. - Guy Cremer, Chief Procurement Officer, working with us since 1989 and leading in the Fleet Management department since 2000. Additionally, Mr. Cremer was recognized with the award for "Rental person of the year" by ERA in June 2023 for his influential role in the shift towards lower carbon emission equipment last year; and - Martin Holmgren: Chief Operations Officer of Nordics and a member of our Strategic Board. Mr. Holmgren is also Vice President of ERA and has worked for almost 30 years in the construction and rental industry. Our highly qualified senior management team is in close contact with our local business directors, since investment decisions strongly benefit from local market knowledge. For example, the choice between opening a greenfield location when expanding into a new region or acquiring an established company in the region is based on local insights about rental company concentration provided by local business leaders: we consider acquisitions when rental concentration is high and greenfield expansion in locations where rental concentration is low. We have an external Advisory Board that meets five times a year and consists of a group of experienced entrepreneurs and leaders. This independent body advises the Management Board on policy matters and the general course of affairs of the Group. In addition, the Advisory Board and its individual members function as a critical sounding board for our Management Board. We are in the process of implementing a two-tier board system by the end of 2025 and have started the search for a Supervisory Board, which will supervise the general course of affairs in the company and the businesses affiliated with the company. It will also supervise the functioning of the Management Board as such and the policy conducted and will provide the Management Board with advice. For further discussion on our management team, see "Management."

Subsubsection Title: Ambitious CSR targets to lead the way in advancing sustainability in the rental industry and mitigate environmental impact throughout the value chain
Subsubsection Text: We strive to lead our company with high business ethics and lead the way in advancing sustainability in the rental industry. We have set ambitious CSR targets to position ourselves as a front runner in the development of a safe and environmentally friendly business and a key partner to our customers in meeting their increasing needs and demands for more sustainable solutions. We believe that the core purpose of rental, compared to ownership, is the achievement of the efficient use of equipment and materials, therefore making a positive contribution to the circular economy. According to a research study ----- led by ERA, efficient use of equipment results in a reduction of approximately 30% to 50% of CO2 emissions (depending on specific user practice) and that the rental business model stimulates such efficient use. Our rental concept allows our customers and their end-customers to meet their objectives and targets in terms of costs, efficiency, quality, safety and to reduce their carbon footprint. CSR topics are at the heart of our business model. We also chose to apply the Global Reporting Initiative 2021 ("GRI 2021") Standards and Disclosures to report our sustainability-related data, to commit to the guidelines of UN Global Compact and to implement the Sustainable Development Goals relevant to our business. In addition, based on a formal materiality assessment, we have identified four focus areas covering all aspects of corporate and social responsibility, including Employee Care, Social Care, Customer Care and Environmental Care. We have also identified, key performance indicators in relation to each topic and set ambitious targets for 2025. We aim to be the leader in sustainable fleet investments, to enable our customers in executing their projects with the lowest level of emissions, while continuing to deliver profitable growth. Our Green Team, which includes members from our fleet, sales and marketing departments, has jointly set out a strategy to invest in anticipation of customer needs and develop ambitious and innovative solutions (including zero emission equipment) in their field. For our fleet, we invest in energy-efficient products to improve our energy performance. For example, our fleet includes electrical two-ton excavators, fully battery-operated six-meter telehandlers and over two-ton electric-wheeled loaders. We also have a wide availability of battery packs and have created solar panel roofs for site huts and new zero emission welfare units, which were both brought to market in 2022. Additionally, our fleet contains more than 1,000 Stage V engines meeting the EU standard for non-road machines with low emissions of particulate matter. Our state-of-the-art fleet adheres to strict environmental and safety performance standards and helps increase our customers' productivity while reducing their emissions footprint. Of our total energy powered fleet units (equipment driven by a motor and with all types of power), approximately 81% is electrically-powered as of December 31, 2022 and we aim to increase this percentage to 85% by 2025. As of June 30, 2023, approximately 67% of our fleet value was comprised of electric, hybrid and gas equipment and not motorized equipment (meaning, equipment without an engine or motor). We have steadily reduced the portion of our diesel-powered equipment as a percentage of fleet value over time, reaching 24% as of June 30, 2023 (excluding Stage V diesel powered equipment). A breakdown of our fleet value by type of power as of June 30, 2023, is presented below.

Notes: Figures between 2008 and 2019 reflect our reported results prepared in accordance with Dutch GAAP and are not comparable with subsequent periods prepared in accordance with IFRS. Figures provided for 2020 reflect the Reconciled Financial Information together with certain pro forma adjustments to reflect the acquisition of Cramo as if it had occurred on January 1, 2020. Figures provided for 2021, 2022 and the last twelve months ended June 30, 2023 reflect our results prepared in accordance with IFRS. (1) For comparability purposes, revenue growth between 2019 and 2020 is expressed as 2020 revenue pro forma to reflect the acquisition of Cramo as if it had occurred on January 1, 2020, compared to 2019 revenue pro forma to reflect the acquisition of Cramo as if it had occurred on January 1, 2019, each prepared under Dutch GAAP. Revenue for 2019 has been prepared solely for illustrative purposes based on management estimates utilizing a simple aggregation of the revenue of Cramo and our revenue for the year ended December 31, 2019. Such information does not reflect any accounting or pro forma adjustments that may be required to present consolidated financial information and is presented for illustrative purposes only. The information and adjustments presented are based upon available information, management estimates and assumptions that are subject to inherent uncertainties, risks and change. See "Risk Factors— _Financial Risks—We present information relating to Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA and other non-IFRS measures in this Offering Memorandum; certain of the data used in calculating this information was unaudited or involved certain estimates and judgments, and accordingly you should not unduly rely on them."_ (2) Represents Free Cash Flow. (3) Total net leverage calculated based on Reported EBITDA. (4) Represents Capital Expenditures (excluding acquisitions). Acquisitions are also an integral part of our growth strategy that we pursue either for geographical expansion (filling in gaps in our existing footprint), increase market share, acquire specialist knowledge, improve our competitive position, or acquire certain assets. We have a clear, defined and well-established acquisitions strategy with a dedicated integration team in place. The success of our international expansion and our ability to effectively integrate acquired companies is demonstrated by our track record of 27 successful acquisitions since 2012. In particular, we demonstrated our disciplined M&A strategy and execution with our transformative acquisition of Cramo in 2020. During the 6 months of the initial integration period, our management executed a clear integration plan to minimize execution risk related to the acquisition, while maintaining a high quality service for our customers and efficiently responding to their needs. In countries where Boels and Cramo had geographic overlap, such as in Germany, Austria, Poland, Czech Republic and Slovakia, we focused our efforts on optimizing our depot network, rebranding and refurbishing Cramo's depots in Central Europe (including Germany), enhancing our cross-selling opportunities and optimizing our back-office functions. We also invested substantially in integrating the fleets in Western, Central and Eastern Europe, increasing the availability of fleet and our flexibility, allowing us to optimize our response to market demands. In 2021 and 2022, we invested in and deployed new equipment categories that meet specific local requirements as a result of our analyses of the local markets, in order to be less dependent on large projects, with the aim to reach small and medium enterprises and retail clients. As a result of such efforts, we were able to successfully integrate our Central European operations in only 10 months and achieved synergies in terms of centralization of our mutual best practices in our key operations: IT, finance, fleet management and human resources through the deployment of our One Boels strategy. As a result of these efforts, we believe we have realized significant synergies, which generate recurring savings in EBITDA and capital expenditures, ----- primarily due to the optimization of our procurement functions, the consolidation of our IT systems and the reduction of our corporate expenses (including as a result of the closing of Cramo's headquarters in Finland). We believe that our acquisition track record, including our ability to integrate companies, positions us for growth while strengthening our local presence. The success of our international expansion supports our financial and operational development and establishes us as a market consolidator in a fragmented equipment rental industry. For further details about certain of our recent acquisitions, "Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of _Operations—Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations—Acquisitions, Geographic Expansion and Depot Openings."_

Subsection Title: Our fleet value as of June 30, 2023 (in € billion)
Subsubsection Text: Furthermore, during 2022, we have made significant progress in offering resource-efficient and sustainable alternatives to customers, supporting them to minimize climate impact: - We increased the share of units powered by electricity within our energy-powered fleet. - We increased the share of Eco-labelled fleet. - We invested over 1.63% of our total fleet value in high-tech, zero-emission machines, with a target to reach 4.7% by 2025. We also continuously work to mitigate our own climate impact by reducing energy consumption, increasing the use of renewable energy and increasing circularity of our products and operations. We reduce, reuse or recycle materials, reduce waste and handle hazardous waste properly. For facilities and installations, we invest in energy efficient products, services and design for energy performance improvement. For example, we have been increasing our energy efficiency while reducing our emissions through investments in sustainable technologies and services, LED lighting, solar panels, ----- better insulation or development of energy management systems. In the year ended December 31, 2022, we reduced our energy use relative to sales by 12%, compared to 2021. In the year ended December 31, 2022, we reduced our gas usage by 28% to 8,900 MWh compared to 2021, which resulted in a reduction of approximately 1,670 tCO2 of our emissions. We are also improving logistics planning in order to limit emissions related to equipment deliveries, as well as increasing our purchase of more renewable energy. We also disclose the Group's greenhouse gas emissions for Scope 1 (direct emissions) and Scope 2 (indirect emissions) with clear reduction targets. In 2022, we announced a number of targets with respect to our carbon emissions for 2025, using 2021 as a baseline, including: - reduce our emissions (calculated in tCO2) relative to sales (Scope 1 and 2) by 20%; - reduce our energy use relative to sales (Scope 1 (direct energy use) and Scope 2 (purchased energy)) by 15%; and - increase our share of renewable electricity to above 92% (compared to 56% in 2022 and 49% in 2021). Simultaneously, we are assessing our scope 3 targets with the main initiatives expected to be set as soon as 2024. For a further discussion of our commitment to environmental and social governance matters and our targets for 2025, see "Business—Environmental, Social and Governance."

Subsubsection Title: Achieve a leading position in all our markets and become a leading partner for our customers
Subsubsection Text: We intend to continue working to provide a high quality, one-stop-shop experience for both individual consumers and businesses, while ensuring that our entire rental range of products meets our customers' evolving demands, in order to achieve a leading market position in each of the markets we address. We believe that we are well-positioned to become the leading partner of our customers in all the geographies we serve. We believe that our customers already recognize us as a preferred one-stop-shop for their rental needs, primarily due to our diversification across products, end markets, general and specialist rental, and our strong European geographic coverage. Our acquisition of Cramo has demonstrated our ambition to keep strengthening and expanding our geographic coverage and diversifying our service offering. We believe we can achieve a leading position in our markets through our strong, long-term partnerships with our customers. In order to strengthen our customer relationships and remain our customers' preferred rental partner, we aim to provide full turn-key solutions, ranging from providing generalist tools to more specialized equipment (including site huts, site safes, traffic sets and sanitation), in addition to value-added services such as logistics. For example, in 2021, we delivered full service rental solutions for a wind farm project in Lithuania by providing site huts, construction equipment and special tools, in addition to access control, on-site maintenance, and helping with planning, transportation, delivery. Since 2022, we provide full turnkey solutions for an automotive Gigafactory located in Berlin-Brandenburg. We combine our proximity to customers and our understanding of their needs in order to continue providing our customers with valueadded services and products. Finally, we intend to continue pursuing our fleet investment strategy, which aims to maintain a complete range of sustainable and safe rental equipment.

Subsubsection Title: Grow through a combination of organic development and bolt-on acquisitions
Subsubsection Text: We have achieved an impressive track record of both sales and EBITDA growth through a strategic combination of strong organic growth and the successful integration of both our transformative and smaller bolt-on acquisitions. Through our acquisition strategy in particular, we have expanded to cover new geographic markets and have diversified our catalogue of products and services. We believe we have significant opportunities to continue growing organically due to our comprehensive network of 759 depots and more than 3,100 DIY shop-in-shops across Europe as of June 30, 2023. We intend to increase the density of our network in less concentrated regions which we believe have a strong potential of profitable growth through our clear greenfield expansion strategy. ----- We also intend to continue evaluating strategic acquisition targets to further strengthen and expand our operations and customer base, to selectively enter new markets over time, in particular in geographic areas with low rental company concentration to increase opportunities for upselling and cross-selling our products. In pursuing such acquisitions, we maintain the same disciplined, targeted, and opportunistic acquisition investment criteria that have historically enabled us to successfully identify acquisition targets and profitably acquire and integrate them. Successful integration of acquisitions is key to our strategy, and we believe we are well-positioned to integrate future acquisitions efficiently and profitably. We have dedicated integration teams supported by local teams with superior knowledge of their local markets to develop synergies in our fleet management, expedite the completion and integration of acquisitions and position us to achieve our long-term success.

Subsubsection Title: Drive digital innovation to increase productivity for our customers and improve our operational efficiency
Subsubsection Text: We have developed and intend to continue to develop digital services in order to improve our customers' experience and boost our operational performance. We believe that we are a leader in the development of new, innovative digital business models in our industry. We have developed and deployed new types of data- and connectivity-based solutions to connect our people, internal processes and fleet to our customers, such as our new smart application for mobile devices, "Equipment Pool", which improves customers' access to equipment and machines, while reducing transportation times to and from customers' construction sites . We believe that we can leverage our digital processes and use of data in a customer-focused manner in order to improve communication between our employees and our customers, better identify customers' needs and facilitate interactions and transactions with customers. Although we already have improved processes and digital tools in place to optimize our customers' experience, we intend to continue enhancing our rental websites, including those of Cramo, Boels Rental and IQ Pass, to add further equipment data and specifications and combine our general and specialist rental fleet in a single platform. We believe that such technological capabilities positions us to achieve the full potential of our one-stop-shop solutions. We also intend to continue leveraging digital tools to streamline and boost efficiency in our internal systems. For example, we have implemented a single group-wide financial system to monitor our cash flows and key performance indicators. We have also implemented our group-wide One Boels strategy in order to continue harmonizing systems and processes based on four pillars: (i) One IT approach; (ii) One financial organization, (iii) One fleet and procurement organization and (iv) One HR approach and organization. We have developed our One Boels strategy as a clear, distinct, and strong organization that focuses not only on our customers' needs, but also boosts our efficiency. We intend to continue enhancing our operational systems and processes to increase our operational and procurement efficiency, improve our strategic relationships with OEMs, strengthen our fleet management and negotiating position for strategic procurement and maintenance of our fleet, and enhance our employee retention.

Subsubsection Title: Maintain top-tier performance as a leading rental company
Subsubsection Text: We aim to maintain our operational performance by systematically improving and optimizing fleet usage, composition and performance. Historically, we have had a more centralized business model where our rental fleet was managed centrally to optimize the allocation of equipment, while local managers organized by countries and depots offered knowledge of local markets. Cramo, on the other side, has historically had a more decentralized business group structure, where operating decisions were made at the country and business-unit level. With the integration of Cramo, we have developed a synergized approach, which aims to combine the best practices of both organizations by centralizing key operations such as procurement or fleet management, while we keep a flexible and locally oriented commercial approach for each market and geography. We believe that this approach, together with our close cooperation with, and monitoring of, our depots, business units and departments, positions us to achieve our strategy, whilst retaining our disciplined and flexible business and financial models.
