Subsubsection Title: Reinforce our commitments to the environment, safety, quality and corporate responsibility
Subsubsection Text: We are committed to promoting and maintaining corporate sustainability and responsibility as a core component of our business. We intend to continue being a leading climate- and resource-efficient rental company, paving the way to enhance sustainability in the rental industry and to reduce our environmental footprint throughout our value chain. We believe that our value chain perspective on sustainability helps us identify how we can optimally manage our impact on the environment while efficiently operating our business. We also strive to meet our customers' increasing needs and demands for more sustainable solutions. ----- We are convinced that maintaining an adequate corporate governance policy is a prerequisite to structure the organization efficiently and effectively and achieve our strategic goals. We also believe that our sustainability policy helps us to manage risks and to consider the interests of all our stakeholders, including our shareholders, our employees and our customers. We discuss our material sustainability topics, focus areas and strategic targets twice a year with our Strategic Board and our Operations Board, and periodically with the Sustainability Steering Committee that we have implemented to help us achieve our sustainability goals. For a further discussion of our commitment to environmental, social and governance matters and our targets for 2025, see "Business—Environmental, Social and Governance."

Our business strategy focuses on profitable growth, further enhancing operational efficiency, strengthening our market position in all segments, expanding our service offerings, developing innovative digital solutions to improve customer efficiency and promoting corporate social responsibility.

On the Issue Date, we will use the proceeds of the Offering to: (i) repay and cancel a portion of the Existing Term Loan B in a principal amount equal to €200.0 million, (ii) repay in full amounts drawn under the Existing Revolving Credit Facility, (iii) fund cash on our balance sheet for general corporate purposes and (iv) pay fees and expenses in connection with the Transactions. See "—The Transactions" and "Use of Proceeds." For descriptions of our current and anticipated indebtedness following the Offering and the use of proceeds therefrom, see "Description of Certain Financing _Arrangements" and "Capitalization."_ The Offering and the application of the proceeds from the Offering as set forth under "Use of Proceeds," are collectively referred to in this Offering Memorandum as the "Transactions." See also "Use of Proceeds," "Capitalization," "Description of the Notes" and "Description of Certain Financing Arrangements."

Subsubsection Title: Upsize of the Existing Revolving Credit Facility
Subsubsection Text: In connection with the Offering, we expect to increase the lender commitments in respect of the Existing Revolving Credit Facility by €35.0 million to be provided by certain affiliates of J.P. Morgan SE. There can be no assurance that such increase to the Existing Revolving Credit Facility will be effected or as to the timing, amount or terms thereof.

We are currently in discussions with the European Investment Bank to obtain an amortizing term loan to support our further investments in 'green' electric equipment in line with the European Investment Bank's commitment to climate action and environmental sustainability. The financing is expected to rank pari passu in right of payment and security with the Notes and the Existing Senior Facilities and only have a minimal impact on our leverage. We will endeavor to close this transaction by the first half of 2024, although no assurances can be made that the financing will be obtained or as to the timing, amount or terms thereof. -----

_This summary highlights selected information about us and about this Offering contained elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. The following summary is not complete and does not contain all the information you should consider before investing in the Notes. The following summary should be read in conjunction with, and is qualified in its entirety by, the more detailed information included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. Before making an investment decision, you should read this entire Offering Memorandum carefully, including the Financial Statements and the notes thereto and the other financial information contained in this Offering Memorandum, as well as the risks described under "Risk Factors" and the sections entitled "Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations" and "Business." Certain defined terms used herein are defined elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum._

The following chart illustrates our simplified corporate structure and principal indebtedness on an as adjusted basis after giving effect to the Transactions, as described under "Use of Proceeds." For a summary of the debt obligations referred to in this chart, see "Description of Certain Financing Arrangements," "Description of the Notes" and "Capitalization." All entities shown below are 100% directly or indirectly owned unless otherwise indicated. This chart does not include all of our subsidiaries or all of our debt obligations. (1) The Issuer is a private company with limited liability (besloten vennootschap met beperkte aansprakelijkheid) incorporated under the laws of the Netherlands. The Issuer is a direct wholly-owned subsidiary of the Parent, which in turn is wholly owned by our CEO, Mr. Pierre Boels Jr., and his family members. See "Shareholders and Related Party Transactions." (2) The Notes will be general senior obligations of the Issuer and will rank pari passu in right of payment with all of the Issuer's existing and future obligations that are not expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Notes, including obligations under the Existing Senior Facilities, and will rank senior in right of payment to all of existing and future obligations that are expressly subordinated in right of payment. The Notes will be effectively senior to all of the existing and future obligations of the Issuer that are not secured by the Collateral, to the extent of the value of such Collateral, and will be effectively subordinated to all of the existing and future obligations of the Issuer that are secured by property or assets that do not also secure the Notes, to the extent of the value of such property or assets securing such other obligations. The Notes will be structurally subordinated to all existing and future obligations (including trade payables) of subsidiaries of the Issuer that do not provide Guarantees. On or about the Issue Date, subject to the terms of the security documents, the Agreed Security Principles and applicable perfection requirements, the Notes and the Guarantees will be secured by (a) the issued shares, certain material bank accounts and material structural intercompany receivables of the Issuer, (b) material structural intercompany receivables owed to the Parent by the Issuer or any material subsidiary, (c) the issued shares, certain material bank accounts and certain material structural intercompany receivables of the Guarantors and (d) substantially all assets of each Guarantor incorporated in England and Wales, substantially all inventory, machinery, plant, trade receivables, vehicles and construction machines of each Guarantor incorporated in Norway and substantially all movable assets of each Guarantor incorporated in Finland and Sweden (by way of a business mortgage). See "Description of Certain Financing Arrangements" and "Description of the Notes—Security." The Collateral may be limited by applicable law or subject to certain defenses that may limit their validity and enforceability. For more information on potential limitations to the security interests, see "Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of the Security and the Guarantees and Certain Insolvency Law _Considerations." The security interests over the Collateral may be released under certain circumstances. The Collateral also secures the Existing_ Senior Facilities on a pari passu basis with the Notes. See "Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Senior Facilities Agreement." (3) The Existing Senior Facilities consist of a €1,450.0 million Existing Term Loan B and a €179.3 million Existing Revolving Credit Facility. The Existing Senior Facilities are guaranteed on a senior basis by the same entities that will guarantee the Notes and secured by the Collateral pari _passu with the Notes. As of June 30, 2023, €131.6 million was drawn under the Existing Revolving Credit Facility. On the Issue Date, a portion_ of the proceeds of the Offering will be used to (a) repay and cancel a portion of the Existing Term Loan B in a principal amount equal to €200.0 million and (b) repay in full amounts drawn under the Existing Revolving Credit Facility. See "Use of Proceeds" and "Description of Certain _Financing Arrangements—Senior Facilities Agreement." In addition, the Group has access to an overdraft facility of approximately €20.0 million._ As of June 30, 2023, the overdraft facility was drawn for €2.9 million. (4) On the Issue Date, the Notes will be guaranteed by the Guarantors. Each Guarantee will be a general senior obligation of the relevant Guarantor and will rank pari passu in right of payment with all of such Guarantor's existing and future obligations that are not expressly subordinated in right of payment to such Guarantee, including obligations under the Existing Senior Facilities, and will rank senior in right of payment to all of the existing and future obligations that are expressly subordinated in right of payment. Each Guarantee will be effectively senior to all existing and future obligations of the applicable Guarantor that are not secured by the Collateral owned by such Guarantor, to the extent of the value of such Collateral, and will be effectively subordinated to all of the existing and future obligations of such Guarantor that are secured by property or assets that do not also secure the Guarantees, to the extent of the value of such property or assets securing such obligations and will be effectively subordinated to all of the existing and future obligations of such Guarantor that are secured by property or assets that do not also secure its Guarantee, to the extent of the value of such property and assets securing such obligations. As of and for the year ended December 31, 2022, the ----- Issuer and the Guarantors represented 87% of our Reported EBITDA (excluding entities with negative Reported EBITDA), 89% of our revenue and 92% of our total assets (including goodwill). The validity and enforceability of the Guarantees and the liability of the Guarantors will be subject to the limitations described in "Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of the Security and the Guarantees and Certain Insolvency Law _Considerations." The Guarantees may be released under certain circumstances._ (5) Certain of the Issuer's subsidiaries will not guarantee the Notes. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, the Issuer's direct and indirect subsidiaries that will not guarantee the Notes did not have any material external borrowings outstanding. -----

Subsection Title: Issuer ........................................................... Boels Topholding B.V., a private company with limited liability (besloten
Subsubsection Text: _vennootschap met beperkte aansprakelijkheid) incorporated under the_ laws of the Netherlands.

Subsection Title: Notes Offered .............................................. €400 million aggregate principal amount of Senior Secured Notes due

Subsubsection Text: on    , 2024. Interest on the Notes will accrue from the Issue Date.

Subsection Title: Denominations ............................................ The Notes will be issued in minimum denominations of €100,000 and
Subsubsection Text: integral multiples of €1,000 in excess thereof. Notes in denominations of less than €100,000 will not be available.

Subsection Title: Ranking of the Notes .................................. The Notes will:
Subsubsection Text: - be general senior obligations of the Issuer; - be secured as set forth under "—Security," on a pari passu basis with the interests granted in favor of the Existing Senior Facilities and certain hedging obligations; - rank pari passu in right of payment with any existing and future obligations of the Issuer that are not expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Notes, including the Issuer's obligations under the Existing Senior Facilities; - rank senior in right of payment to any existing and future obligations of the Issuer that are expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Notes; - be effectively senior to any existing and future obligations of the Issuer that are not secured by the Collateral, to the extent of the value of such Collateral; - be effectively subordinated to any existing or future obligations of the Issuer and its subsidiaries that are secured by property or assets that do not secure the Notes, to the extent of the value of the property or assets securing such obligations; - be structurally subordinated to any existing or future obligations of the subsidiaries of the Issuer that are not Guarantors, including obligations owed to trade creditors; and ----- - be guaranteed on a senior joint and several basis by the Guarantors.

Subsection Title: Guarantees .................................................. On the Issue Date, the Issuer's obligations under the Notes will be
Subsubsection Text: guaranteed (collectively, the "Guarantees") on a senior secured basis by the Guarantors. The obligations of each Guarantor will be limited as described under "Description of the Notes—Guarantees." Each Guarantee will be subject to certain contractual and legal limitations. See "Limitations on Validity _and Enforceability of the Security and the Guarantees and Certain Insolvency Law Considerations." Each Guarantee will be subject to the_ terms of the Intercreditor Agreement, including certain payment blockage, standstill and turnover provisions. See "Description of Certain Financing _Arrangements—Intercreditor Agreement." Each Guarantee will be subject_ to release under certain circumstances. See "Description of the Notes— _Guarantees—Release of the Guarantees."_ As of and for the year ended December 31, 2022, the Issuer and the Guarantors represented 87% of our Reported EBITDA (excluding entities with negative Reported EBITDA), 89% of our revenue and 92% of our total assets (including goodwill).

Subsection Title: Ranking of the Guarantees ........................ The Guarantee of each Guarantor will:
Subsubsection Text: - be a general senior obligation of such Guarantor; - be secured as set forth under "—Security," on a pari passu basis with the interests granted in favor of the Existing Senior Facilities and certain hedging obligations; - rank pari passu in right of payment with any existing and future obligations of the relevant Guarantor that are not expressly subordinated in right of payment to such Guarantee, including such Guarantor's obligations under the Existing Senior Facilities; - rank senior in right of payment to any existing and future obligations of such Guarantor that are expressly subordinated in right of payment to such Guarantee; - be effectively senior to any existing and future obligations of the applicable Guarantor that are not secured by the Collateral owned by such Guarantor, to the extent of the value of such Collateral; - be effectively subordinated to any existing or future obligations of such Guarantor that are secured by property or assets that do not secure such Guarantee to the extent of the value of the property or assets securing such other obligations; - be structurally subordinated to any existing or future obligations of the subsidiaries of such Guarantor that do not provide Guarantees, including obligations owed to trade creditors; and - be subject to the limitations described herein and in "Risk _Factors—Risks Related to the Notes, the Guarantees and Our Structure—Each Guarantee and security interest will be subject to certain limitations on enforcement and may be limited by applicable law or subject to certain defenses that may limit its validity and enforceability" and "Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of the Security and the Guarantees and Certain Insolvency Law Considerations."_ ----- The Guarantees may be released under certain circumstances. See "Risk _Factors—Risks Related to the Notes, the Guarantees and Our Structure— There are circumstances other than repayment or discharge of the Notes under which the Collateral securing the Notes and the Guarantees will be released automatically, without your consent or the consent of the Trustee," "Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Intercreditor Agreement" and "Description of the Notes—Guarantees—Release of the Guarantees."_

Subsection Title: Security ........................................................ On or about the Issue Date, subject to the Agreed Security Principles and
Subsubsection Text: applicable perfection requirements, the Notes will be secured by: - the issued shares, certain material bank accounts and material structural intercompany receivables of the Issuer; - material structural intercompany receivables owed to the Parent by the Issuer or any material subsidiary; - the issued shares, certain material bank accounts and certain material structural intercompany receivables of the Guarantors; and - substantially all assets of each Guarantor incorporated in England and Wales, substantially all inventory, machinery, plant, trade receivables, vehicles and construction machines of each Guarantor incorporated in Norway (in each case, by way of a floating charge) and substantially all movable assets of each Guarantor incorporated in Finland and Sweden (by way of a business mortgage) (collectively, the "Collateral"). The Collateral also secures the Existing Senior Facilities and certain hedging obligations on a pari passu basis. The Collateral may be limited by applicable law or subject to certain defenses that may limit their validity and enforceability. For more information on the security interests granted, see "Description of the Notes—Security" and for more information on potential limitations to the security interests, see "Limitations on Validity _and Enforceability of the Security and the Guarantees and Certain Insolvency Law Considerations" and "Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Notes, the Guarantees and Our Structure."_ References to pari passu security interests include security interests that were created subsequent in time and thus in ranking, but are contractually pari passu with prior ranking security and entitled to equal treatment with other prior ranking security and secured creditors pursuant to the Intercreditor Agreement. See "Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Notes, _the Guarantees and Our Structure—Holders of the Notes must rely on the effectiveness of the Intercreditor Agreement to implement parity among the secured parties."_ The security interests over the Collateral may be released under certain circumstances. See "Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Notes, the _Guarantees and Our Structure—There are circumstances other than repayment or discharge of the Notes under which the Collateral securing the Notes and the Guarantees will be released automatically, without your consent or the consent of the Trustee," "Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Intercreditor Agreement" and "Description of the Notes— Security—Release of Security."_

Subsection Title: Additional Amounts ................................... All payments by or on behalf of the Issuer or any Guarantor (or any
Subsubsection Text: surviving entity) under or with respect to the Notes or any Guarantee will ----- be made free and clear of, and without withholding or deduction for taxes, unless required by law. If any withholding or deduction for or on account of any taxes imposed by any relevant taxing jurisdiction is required, the Issuer, the Guarantor or surviving entity, as the case may be, will pay such additional amounts as may be necessary to ensure that the net amount received by each holder of the Notes after such withholding or deduction will be not less than the amount the holder would have received if such taxes had not been required to be withheld or deducted, subject to certain exceptions. See "Description of the Notes—Guarantees—Additional _Amounts."_

Subsection Title: Optional Redemption of Notes .................. Prior to     , 2025, the Issuer may redeem all or a portion of the Notes
Subsubsection Text: at a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount of such Notes plus the applicable "make-whole" premium set forth in this Offering Memorandum, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the redemption date. Prior to     , 2025, the Issuer may during each twelve month period following the Issue Date redeem up to 10% of the original aggregate principal amount of the Notes (including any Additional Notes) at a redemption price equal to 103% of the principal amount thereof plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the redemption date. Prior to     , 2025, the Issuer may redeem on one or more occasions up to 40% of the original aggregate principal amount of the Notes (including any Additional Notes) using the net proceeds from certain equity offerings at a redemption price equal to      % of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the redemption date; provided that, at least 50% of the original aggregate principal amount of the Notes (including any Additional Notes) remains outstanding after the redemption. On or after     , 2025, the Issuer may redeem all or a portion of the Notes at the redemption prices set forth in this Offering Memorandum under the caption "Description of the Notes—Optional Redemption" plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the redemption date. See "Description of the Notes—Optional Redemption."

Subsection Title: Redemption for Taxation ........................... In the event of certain developments affecting taxation, the Issuer may
Subsubsection Text: redeem the Notes in whole, but not in part, at any time, at a redemption price of 100% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the redemption date. See "Description of the Notes—Optional Redemption—Redemption _Upon Changes in Withholding Taxes."_

Subsection Title: Change of Control ...................................... Upon the occurrence of certain events constituting a "change of control,"
Subsubsection Text: the Issuer is required to offer to repurchase all outstanding Notes at a purchase price in cash of 101% of the principal amount thereof on the date of purchase plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the date of repurchase. See "Description of the Notes—Certain Covenants—Change of Control."

Subsection Title: Tender Offers .............................................. In connection with any tender offers for the Notes, if holders of not less
Subsubsection Text: than 90% in aggregate principal amount of the applicable outstanding Notes validly tender and do not withdraw such Notes in such tender offer and the Issuer, or any third party making such a tender offer in lieu of the Issuer, purchases, all of the Notes validly tendered and not withdrawn by such holders, the Issuer or such third party will have the right to redeem the Notes that remain outstanding in whole, but not in part, following such ----- purchase at a price equal to the price offered to each other holder of Notes (excluding any early tender or incentive fee) plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the redemption date. See "Description of the Notes—Optional Redemption—General."

Subsection Title: Certain Covenants ...................................... The Indenture will contain covenants that, among other things, limit the
Subsubsection Text: ability of the Issuer and its Restricted Subsidiaries to: - incur additional debt and issue guarantees and preferred stock; - make certain restricted payments, including dividends and other distributions; - make certain investments or loans, including participating in joint ventures; - repay or redeem subordinated debt or share capital; - create or incur certain liens; - impose restrictions on the ability of subsidiaries to pay dividends or make other payments to the Issuer; - sell, lease or transfer certain assets, including shares of any of our Restricted Subsidiaries; - guarantee certain types of our other indebtedness without also guaranteeing the Notes; - effect a merger or consolidation of, or sell, all or substantially all of our assets or all of the assets of certain companies within the Group; - enter into certain transactions with affiliates; and - impair the security interests for the benefit of the holders of the Notes. Certain of the covenants will be suspended if and for as long as the Notes achieve and maintain investment-grade ratings. See "Description of the _Notes—Certain Covenants—Suspension of Covenants on Achievement of Investment Grade Status."_ Each of these covenants is subject to a number of important limitations and exceptions as described under "Description of the Notes—Certain _Covenants."_

Subsection Title: Transfer Restrictions ................................. The Notes and the Guarantees have not been, and will not be, registered
Subsubsection Text: under the U.S. Securities Act, or the securities laws of any state of the United States or other jurisdiction, and may not be offered or sold within the United States, except pursuant to an exemption from, or in a transaction not subject to, the registration requirements of the U.S. Securities Act and applicable securities laws of any state of the United States or other jurisdiction. See "Notice to Investors" for further detail and additional restrictions applicable in the EEA and the United Kingdom.

Subsection Title: Use of Proceeds ........................................... On the Issue Date, we will use the proceeds of the Offering to: (i) repay
Subsubsection Text: and cancel a portion of the Existing Term Loan B in a principal amount equal to €200.0 million, (ii) repay in full amounts drawn under the Existing Revolving Credit Facility, (iii) fund cash on our balance sheet for general corporate purposes and (iv) pay fees and expenses in connection with the Transactions. See "Use of Proceeds." -----

Subsection Title: No Prior Market ......................................... The Notes will be new securities for which there is no prior market.
Subsubsection Text: Although certain of the Initial Purchasers have informed us that they intend to make a market in the Notes, they are not obligated to do so and they may discontinue market-making at any time without notice. Accordingly, we cannot assure you that a liquid market for the Notes will develop or be maintained.

Subsection Title: Listing .......................................................... Application will be made to the Authority for the listing of and permission
Subsubsection Text: to deal in the Notes on the Official List of the Exchange.

Subsection Title: Governing Law ........................................... The Indenture, the Guarantees provided therein and the Notes will be
Subsubsection Text: governed by the laws of the State of New York. The Intercreditor Agreement and the Existing Senior Facilities Agreement are governed by English Law. The Security Documents will (subject to certain exceptions) be governed by the laws applicable to the relevant asset.

Subsection Title: Trustee ......................................................... BNY Mellon Corporate Trustee Services Limited Paying Agent ............................................... The Bank of New York Mellon, London Branch Registrar and Transfer Agent ................... The Bank of New York Mellon SA/NV, Dublin Branch Security Agent ............................................ Coöperatieve Rabobank U.A. Risk Factors ................................................ Investing in the Notes involves substantial risks. You should carefully
Subsubsection Text: consider all the information in this Offering Memorandum and, in particular, you should evaluate the specific risk factors set forth in the "Risk _Factors" section of this Offering Memorandum before making a decision_ whether to invest in the Notes. -----

Subsubsection Text: (i) In 2020, this primarily represents the additional restructuring expenses as a result of our cost reduction plan following the onset of the COVID19 pandemic amounting to €7.5 million, additional costs to settle the Cramo stock option plan and termination fees amounting to €3.6 million and Cramo Central Europe integration expenses. In 2021, this primarily represents an additional donation to the jubilee provision and a decrease in discount rate impact amounting to €2.2 million and additional charges as a result of the establishment of the shared service center in the Nordic countries amounting to €0.9 million. In 2022, this primarily reflects the release of discounted provisions for employee benefits due to an increased discount rate amounting to €(2.4) million and release of bonus accruals amounting to €(0.5) million, which was partially offset by certain severance costs paid to employees connected to the acquisition of Eekels Pompen amounting to €0.2 million. In the six months ended June 30, 2023, this primarily represents the payment of additional performance-related bonuses related to the fourth quarter of 2022 amounting to €0.5 million. (ii) In 2020, this primarily represents advisory fees paid related to the Cramo acquisition amounting to €6.8 million and advisory fees in relation to the integration of Cramo Central Europe in Boels amounting to €0.8 million. In 2021, this primarily relates to a provision for a legal claim in Arlon (Belgium) amounting to €1.6 million and additional expenses relating to a property tax claim in Germany amounting to €1.4 million. In 2022, this primarily represents the release of accruals for invoices from prior years amounting to €(1.8) million, the release of over payments to debtors amounting to €(0.8) million and insurance compensation related to a depot destroyed by flooding in 2021 amounting to €(0.2) million. In the six months ended June 30, 2023, this primarily represents the release of an accrual amounting to €(4.0) million and old accounts receivable balances in connection with our trade receivable financing amounting to €(1.9) million. (iii) In 2020, this primarily represents insurance compensation related to the destruction of a property in Germany, partially offset by the book value of such property, amounting to €(0.7) million, a book gain on a sold property in the Netherlands amounting to €(0.4) million and a release of a provision taken in prior years amounting to €(0.2) million. In 2021, this primarily represents the result of a sale and leaseback transaction in Belgium amounting to €(0.7) million and a release of accruals amounting to €(0.3) million, offset by additional Cramo Central Europe integration expenses amounting to €1.2 million and additional provisions related to integration risks of certain acquisitions amounting to €0.6 million. In the six months ended June 30, 2023, this primarily represents the book gain on a sale and lease back transaction in Germany amounting to €(0.9) million. (iv) Represents the movement in the provision for doubtful debtors, which we have considered exceptional since the transition to IFRS in the year ended December 31, 2022. (v) Our audited consolidated financial statements and the financial information presented in this Offering Memorandum as of and for the year ended December 31, 2020 reflect the results of Cramo for the period from February 1, 2020 to December 31, 2020 only. For the month ended January 31, 2020, Cramo's estimated revenue and estimated Reported EBITDA was €44.4 million and €13.4 million, respectively. Section Title: SUMMARY CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL AND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: _The following tables set forth our financial information as of the dates and for the periods indicated below. We first prepared annual consolidated financial statements in accordance with IFRS for the year ended December 31, 2022. Until December 31, 2021, we prepared our consolidated financial statements in accordance with Dutch GAAP. In order to aid in the understanding of our financial information on a more comparable basis, the following tables present certain financial information for the year ended December 31, 2020 on the basis of the Reconciled Financial Information. The Reconciled Financial Information has not been audited, is not fully comparable with our financial information for subsequent periods and should not be regarded as a substitute for our FY 2020 Financial Statements prepared in accordance with Dutch GAAP. See "Presentation of Financial Information" for additional information on the presentation of financial information in this "Summary Consolidated Financial and Other Information." For a reconciliation of the Reconciled Financial Information for the year ended December 31, 2020 to the FY 2020 Financial Statements prepared under Dutch GAAP and a discussion of the differences between Dutch GAAP and IFRS, see "Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Certain Differences Between Dutch GAAP and IFRS." In addition, the following tables include unaudited consolidated financial information for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023. The unaudited consolidated financial information for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023 has been prepared solely for illustrative purposes for this Offering Memorandum and has not been audited or reviewed. The unaudited consolidated financial information for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023 is not necessarily indicative of the results that may be expected for any future period and should not be used as the basis for or prediction of an annualized calculation. See "Presentation of Financial Information—LTM Financial Information" for additional information. We also present certain unaudited consolidated financial information on an as adjusted basis, to illustrate the effect the Transactions would have had on certain of our financial results for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023 or on our financial position as of June 30, 2023, as applicable. The unaudited as adjusted consolidated financial information is for informational purposes only and is not intended to represent or to be indicative of the consolidated results of operations or financial position we would have reported had the Transactions been completed as of July 1, 2022, in the case of our as adjusted total debt interest expense and as adjusted senior secured debt interest expense, or as of June 30, 2023, in the case of our as adjusted cash and cash equivalents, as adjusted total debt, as adjusted total net debt, as adjusted senior secured debt and as adjusted senior secured net debt. The unaudited as adjusted consolidated financial information should not be taken as indicative of our future consolidated results of operations or financial position. Our historical results may not be indicative of our future results following completion of the Transactions. The unaudited as adjusted consolidated financial information has not been prepared in accordance with IFRS or any other generally accepted accounting standards. The following tables also contain Non-IFRS Measures and ratios that are not presented in accordance with IFRS, are not identified as accounting measures under IFRS and therefore should not be considered a substitute for, or superior to, the equivalent measures calculated and presented in accordance with IFRS or those calculated using financial measures that are prepared in accordance with IFRS. See "Presentation of Financial Information—Non-IFRS Measures." You should also read the following information in conjunction with the "Presentation of Financial Information," "Risk Factors," "Capitalization" and "Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations."_ -----

Subsubsection Title: We are vulnerable to fluctuations and deteriorations in the economic conditions in the industries and markets in which we and our customers operate.
Subsubsection Text: We may be negatively impacted by economic downturns and uncertainty in any of the countries in which we operate or the global markets generally, as adverse economic conditions may reduce commercial activity, cause disruption and volatility and increase rates of default and bankruptcy. The demand for our products and services is dependent on, among other factors, the industries in which our customers operate, the general economy and the stability of the global credit markets. During economic downturns, certain of our customers may, for example, suspend or delay projects and events or become more likely to go out of business or default on their payment obligations towards us. We serve a large number of customers, with a significant portion of our business being derived from construction, infrastructure, civil engineering and industrial activities. Many of the industries we serve are cyclical and seasonal by nature, with activity levels that tend to increase during periods of economic growth, decline during economic downturns and vary from quarter to quarter. Consequently, a downturn in construction, infrastructure, civil engineering or industrial activities, or the economy as a whole, generally leads to decreased demand for our equipment. Downturns also intensify price competition as equipment rental providers seek to increase utilization of idle equipment, and inflation can result in increased operating expenses that we may not be able to fully pass onto our customers. For example, for the six months ended June 30, 2023, our employee benefits expenses outstripped our revenue growth, in part because we were unable to fully pass along the cost increases to our customers at the same rate as our costs increased. In particular, some of our operating expenses, such as depreciation of right-of-use assets (which are linked to real estate lease payments) and personnel charges in specific countries, are linked to indices, including the Consumer Price Index, which may increase due to inflation. Furthermore, any extended period of inflation may lead to a stagflation or recession, which could in turn lead to the postponement of construction, infrastructure, civil engineering and other industrial activities, thereby lowering the demand for our services. See "—A regional or global health pandemic, such as the COVID-19 pandemic, may adversely affect our business and _exacerbate other risks to which our business is exposed."_ We operate across four geographic regions: the Netherlands, Central Europe, Northern Europe, and Other Countries. In the last twelve months ended June 30, 2023, we generated 23.8%, 35.3%, 37.8% and 3.0% of our total revenue in the Netherlands, Central Europe, Northern Europe and Other Countries regions, respectively. Within these regions, we are particularly exposed to the economic conditions in the Netherlands, Sweden and Germany. Our end markets may be impacted, either temporarily or over the long-term, by changes in: - government infrastructure spending; - spending levels by either public or private customers; - the credit markets and other economic conditions affecting our customers' ability to undertake new projects or hold events, or otherwise impacting customers' demand for our products and services; - the cost of construction and other materials; or - weather conditions affecting a particular region. Changes in these or other factors caused by deterioration in the construction, infrastructure, civil engineering and other industrial sectors could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial position, results of operations and cash flows in the future. If in any of our markets the economic conditions deteriorate or a return to economic growth is further delayed, our business, financial position, results of operations and cash flows could be materially adversely affected. -----

Subsubsection Title: The equipment rental industry is highly competitive, which puts downward pressure on prices.
Subsubsection Text: The equipment rental industry is highly competitive. Many of the markets in which we operate are served by numerous competitors, ranging from national, multi-regional and international equipment rental companies to small, independent businesses with a limited number of locations. In addition, we may encounter increased competition from existing competitors or new market entrants in the future. We face competition principally from pan-European and national rental companies, as well as from regional and local entities. Some of our competitors may have greater financial, marketing and other resources than we do. Our competitors may be more specialized or may have greater name recognition in some markets. We also face competition from smaller competitors operating at regional or local levels, many of which benefit from a strong market presence and local relationships. Over time, our competitors, whether pan-European, national, regional or local, could consolidate their businesses, and the diversified service offerings or increased synergies of these consolidated businesses could increase competition in the markets in which we operate. Competition is based on an array of different factors, some of which are interrelated, including: speed of integrating new or emerging technologies; technical specifications and condition of equipment; engineering solutions and technical know-how; range and timeliness of the products and services offered; availability of equipment; client relationships; ability to quickly adapt to client requirements; a track record of delivery; the willingness to accept higher contractual risks in tender contracts; price; compliance with health and safety and environmental standards; brand name and reputation; resources and budget available for marketing and sales of products and services; and relevant certifications. If we are unable to maintain our competitiveness in relation to one or more of these factors, we may not be able to grow our market share and may potentially lose existing client relationships, which would materially adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows. In addition, the equipment rental market is increasingly becoming digitized and there is increased focus on the sustainability of equipment, factors which are beginning to be used as differentiators within the market and are central to our business strategy. There can be no assurance that we will be able to capitalize on such trends or achieve the expected benefits of this strategy, or that we will be able to successfully implement and maintain the necessary technologies, processes, and capabilities. Our digitalization strategy involves significant investments in our websites, enterprise resource planning ("ERP") tools, asset monitoring and maintenance systems, online platforms and data systems, many of which are provided by third-party service providers and partners. There can be no assurance that this strategy will be successful, will generate the anticipated benefits and will not increase our exposure to other risks related to increasing reliance on information technology systems and third-party service providers. See "—Risks related to our Business—Disruptions in _our information technology systems could limit our capacity to effectively monitor and control our operations" and "— Risks related to our Business—Our business and reputation may be adversely affected by the actions of third parties."_ Furthermore, we have invested, and expect to continue to invest, in growing our fleet of electrical, hybrid or batterypowered equipment. These investments can be costly and may become obsolete or ineffective due to changing customer preferences, market conditions, technological developments or other factors. Our customers might choose to use the services of our competitors rather than ours. Although our top 10 customers at Group level only represented approximately 7.4% of our revenue for the year ended December 31, 2022, our results would be negatively affected if we were to lose one or more of our key customers to our competitors or if such customers were to decrease their business with us for any reason. These or other changes to the competitive landscape of our industry could result in a loss of market share, decreased revenue and a decline in profitability. From time to time, we or our competitors may attempt to compete effectively by lowering rental rates or prices. To the extent we lower rental rates or increase our fleet in order to retain or increase market share, our operating margins could be adversely affected. In addition, some of our operating expenses, such as depreciation of right-of-use assets (which are linked to real estate lease payments) and personnel charges in specific countries, are linked to indices, including consumer price indices, which may increase due to inflation. As such, price pressure can be particularly acute in an inflationary macroeconomic environment where we endeavor to offset increased operating costs, including the cost of purchasing equipment, by increasing the rental rates and prices that we charge our customers, and we may not always be able to sufficiently raise rates or prices to offset the impact of inflation on our costs. In addition, we may not be able to match a competitor's price reductions or fleet investment, which could cause our customers to reduce their level of business with us. Termination of contractual arrangements by our customers may result in decreased market share and revenue, either of which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

Subsubsection Title: Future technological developments may render our current rental fleet technologically obsolete before the end of the initially estimated economic life.
Subsubsection Text: While technological development in the types of tools and equipment that we have traditionally focused our business on has been relatively slow as compared with other sectors that are characterized by more rapid technological change, our rental fleet is increasingly technologically advanced and dependent on complex systems and hardware ----- (including batteries) for their continued operation. Rapid technological evolution and disruptive technologies, failure to upgrade equipment with new technology in time and related changes in laws and regulations (for example, through governments requiring the use of lower emissions technology or by customers actively selecting more sustainable options), may render components of our rental fleet technologically obsolete or redundant prior to the end of their planned useful rental life. Although we seek to sell such redundant or obsolete products on the secondary market, a secondary market for such products may not exist or may be insufficient for our resale needs, which would adversely affect the prices at which we are able to sell and could require us to recognize impairments. Technical obsolescence and redundancy may materially adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

Subsubsection Title: A regional or global health pandemic, such as the COVID-19 pandemic, may adversely affect our business and exacerbate other risks to which our business is exposed.
Subsubsection Text: Public health crises, epidemics or pandemics could materially and adversely affect our business. For example, governments around the world, including in most countries where we operate our activities, imposed restrictive measures to battle the spread of the respiratory disease COVID-19, including travel restrictions, curfews, lockdowns, quarantines and shutdowns of businesses and workplaces. During the year ended December 31, 2020, our business operations were adversely affected by the COVID-19 pandemic. Results differed by country and by end market depending on the severity of the government restrictions imposed and the severity of the pandemic. For example, the suspension of large gatherings and events caused demand for our products and services from the events end market to sharply contract. Overall, we estimate that, on a like-for-like basis reflecting the acquisition of Cramo in 2020, we experienced a mid-single digit revenue decline in the year ended December 31, 2020, compared to the year ended December 31, 2019. The decrease in our level of activity, in line with the decrease in market activity, was the sharpest in Italy, Austria, Belgium and the United Kingdom, where strict lockdown measures were imposed. There can be no assurance that a similar public health crisis will not occur again in the future on a global or regional basis and have a materially adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

Subsubsection Title: Our international operations expose us to risks inherent to international business, any of which could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.
Subsubsection Text: We have operations in 18 countries across Europe. As a result, we are subject to numerous, rapidly evolving and complex laws and regulations which govern, among other things, labor matters, immigration, health and safety, financial reporting standards, corporate governance, tax, trade regulations, export controls, and competitive practices in each jurisdiction where we conduct our business. In addition, changes in regulations could impact the ability of rental operators to utilize their equipment in certain types of projects, affecting the competitive landscape in those projects, as well as in other areas in which the non-conforming equipment may be redeployed. Furthermore, we need to comply with various local standards and practices of different regulatory, tax, judicial and administrative bodies specific to each jurisdiction in which we operate. Further, we are also reliant on local managers to oversee the day-to-day functioning of our branches and to ensure their compliance with local law, and we may be subject to risks related to such compliance, including issues that may arise as a result of insufficient oversight. In such cases, we could be fined or otherwise sanctioned by regulators, which could adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows. There are multiple risks associated with the international nature of our operations, including inconsistent regulations across jurisdictions, unanticipated changes in the regulatory environment, political instability (such as the threat of war, terrorist attacks or civil unrest) and import and export restrictions. Furthermore, these risks may be greater in certain areas where we operate. Any of these events may affect our employees, reputation, business or financial results as well as our ability to achieve our strategy, including the following specific business risks: - adverse economic developments in economies around the world; - social and political instability in a number of countries around the world (such as the Russian invasion of Ukraine); - potential terrorist attacks; - epidemics and pandemics, which may adversely affect our workforce, suppliers and customers; - adverse changes in governmental policies, especially those affecting trade and investment and any regulations impacting the equipment rental business or commercial operations generally; ----- - differing local product preferences and requirements; - pressures on management time and attention due to the complexities of overseeing multinational operations; - challenges in maintaining, staffing, managing multinational operations; - differing tax and regulatory regimes; - differing labor laws and collective bargaining regimes; - enforcement of remedies in various jurisdictions; - the foreign currency translation and transaction risks of operating in euro; - the risk that the business partners upon whom we depend will not perform as expected; - obstacles to the repatriation of earnings and cash; - reduced protection for intellectual property in some countries; - compliance with applicable antitrust and other regulatory and regulations relating to potential future acquisitions; - price controls; - ownership regulations; and - inflation, recession, fluctuations in foreign currency exchange and interest rates, burdensome fiscal policies and transfer restrictions. For example, on February 24, 2022, Russian military forces commenced a war against Ukraine, and conflict and disruption in the region is likely to continue. Although the length, impact and outcome of the ongoing military conflict in Ukraine are highly unpredictable, this conflict has led and could continue to lead to significant market and other disruptions, including significant volatility in commodity prices and the supply of energy resources, instability in financial markets, supply chain interruptions, political and social instability, as well as an increase in cyber-attacks. We have historically had indirect operations in Russia through Fortrent LLC ("Fortrent"), a 50%-owned joint venture with Ramirent Oyj, and which generated a gain of €2.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2022, which was accounted for in our consolidated financial statements under the equity method. Considering the level of uncertainty due to the geopolitical situation resulting from the war in Ukraine and the high volatility of the Russian ruble, we fully impaired our investment in Fortrent in the year ended December 31, 2022, which included the write-down of the full amount of the carrying value of our investment in Fortrent amounting to €10.9 million, the depreciation of certain receivables amounting to €0.9 million and the reversal of the net result of Fortrent amounting to a gain of €2.6 million for the period. In the six months ended June 30, 2023, we reversed the net result of Fortrent amounting to a gain of €1.1 million for the period. In June 2022, we, together with our joint venture partner, decided to sell Fortrent. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, our interest in Fortrent continues to be held for sale. See also "—Risks related to our Legal and Regulatory Environment— _Our business is subject to various legal and regulatory compliance risks, including those involving antitrust, anti-money laundering, anti-bribery or anti-corruption laws and regulations and sanctions."_ We are actively monitoring the situation in Ukraine and Russia and assessing its impact on our business. The extent and duration of the military action, sanctions and resulting market disruptions could be significant and could potentially have a substantial impact on the global economy and our business for an unknown period of time. Although we do not have any current activities in Russia or Ukraine, we have activities in Scandinavia, Poland and the Baltic States, and if the conflict intensifies or expands beyond Ukraine, it could have an adverse impact on our business. For example, we may be forced to reorganize, reduce or terminate business operations in geographical areas where our employees, partners or subcontractors would otherwise be subject to unacceptable economic or personal risks, which could have an adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operation and cash flows. -----

Subsubsection Title: We may not be able to execute our growth strategy.
Subsubsection Text: We have historically expanded our business through a combination of strategic acquisitions and organic growth. Our growth strategy depends in part on our ability to identify attractive acquisition candidates and successfully integrate them into our business. Acquisitions are subject to several risks and there can be no assurance that we will be able to identify attractive acquisition candidates in the future or complete the acquisition of any identified candidates at commercially acceptable prices or terms. In particular, our industry is experiencing rapid consolidation which could impact our ability to achieve our strategy. See also "—The success of our strategy depends in part on our ability to grow through _acquisitions and integrate acquisitions into our business." Our growth strategy also depends in part on our ability to_ successfully identify and open new depots, both in countries where we already have an established presence as well as other countries to which we may decide to expand in the future. There can be no assurance that we will be able to identify attractive new depot locations and successfully open and operate them. Opening new depots requires significant investments and management attention and may involve risks associated with entering new markets, including markets where we face significant competition. We may not have sufficient management, financial and other resources to successfully identify and operate such new depots. Any significant diversion of management's attention, unexpected cost associated with or any major difficulties encountered in acquiring new businesses or operating new depots could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows, and make it more difficult for us to achieve our strategy. Furthermore, general economic conditions or unfavorable global capital and credit markets could affect the timing and extent to which we can make strategic acquisitions and open new depots, which could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows. Furthermore, the success of our strategy, in particular with respect to organic growth, depends on our ability to accurately forecast trends. Our decisions about investments in new equipment, for example, are based in significant part on our views of future demand, and any failure to accurately predict demand could negatively affect our growth prospects. If anticipated growth does not occur, we may not earn the level of returns that we hope to achieve on investments made during the bottom of the cycle. Alternatively, if growth is greater than expected, we may not have a fleet of appropriate size and mix. More generally, uncertainty regarding future product demand in the markets in which we operate, or markets in which we seek to enter, could cause us to maintain excess equipment inventory and increase our capital expenditures beyond what is efficient. Alternatively, this forecasting difficulty could cause a shortage of equipment for rental that could result in an inability to satisfy demand for our products and a loss of market share which could in turn materially adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

Subsubsection Title: The success of our strategy depends in part on our ability to grow through acquisitions and integrate acquisitions into our business.
Subsubsection Text: Historically, we have achieved growth in part through acquisitions and our strategy assumes that some future growth will occur inorganically, through further acquisitions of businesses that we believe complement or enhance our existing products, services, markets, capabilities or technologies. For example, in February 2020, we acquired Cramo Plc ("Cramo"), a provider of equipment rental and modular space solutions and greatly expanded our operations in the Nordics. Although the integration of the Cramo business into our Central Europe region is largely complete, we are continuing to undertake significant integration projects with respect to management structures and back-office functions, through our various "One-projects", including One-Finance, One-Fleet, One-HR and One-IT. A failure to successfully execute any of these integration projects on time, on budget and as envisaged could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows. There can be no assurance that we will be able to identify attractive acquisition candidates in the future or complete the acquisition of any identified candidates at favorable prices or on advantageous terms. We expect to face competition for acquisition candidates, which may limit the number of acquisition opportunities we have and lead to higher acquisition costs. We may not have the financial resources necessary to consummate any acquisitions or the ability to obtain the necessary funds on satisfactory terms. Furthermore, general economic conditions or unfavorable global capital and credit markets could affect the timing and extent to which we successfully acquire new businesses. In general, the risks associated with acquisitions, which could materially adversely affect our business, results of operations, financial condition and cash flows, include the following: - we may lose sales and incur substantial costs, delays or other operational or financial problems in integrating acquired businesses and integration may be more costly and take longer than expected; - we may not achieve financial and operational synergies on a timely basis or without significant costs, if at all; - acquisitions may divert management's attention from the operation of the existing business; ----- - the assumptions underlying the business plans supporting the valuations of the acquisitions and expected synergies may prove inaccurate, in particular with respect to the future performance of the acquired businesses; - we may be forced to divest or reduce the scope of certain businesses to obtain the necessary regulatory authorizations, in particular with respect to anti-trust authorizations; - we may need to write down goodwill and certain other intangible assets from our balance sheet if our initial estimates of the value of an acquired business are higher than actual results; - we may be further exposed to risks of fluctuations in currency exchange rates; - we may not be able to retain key personnel of an acquired company, which could lead to loss of institutional knowledge and customer relationships; - we may not be able to retain existing customers of the acquired business; - we may experience corporate or market cannibalization; - we may face increased competition; - we may operate an acquired company as a joint venture with partners with whom we lack a longstanding relationship; and - we may encounter unanticipated events, circumstances or liabilities related to the acquired businesses, their integration and the growth of our business, particularly in geographic areas in which we have not previously operated. In addition to the risks described above, the integration of acquired businesses may be more difficult and take more time due to logistical, regulatory, linguistic, cultural and other factors such as our relative lack of familiarity with a given market and its economic, political and social dynamics. If we are not successful in implementing our acquisition strategy or integrating such acquisitions, or if some or all of our existing or future acquisitions prove ultimately to be unsuccessful, our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows could be materially adversely affected.

Subsubsection Title: We depend on equipment manufacturers to obtain adequate rental equipment for our fleet on a timely basis.
Subsubsection Text: We purchase most of our rental equipment from well-known original equipment manufacturers. We rely on our relationships with original equipment manufacturers to centralize our procurement and benefit from economies of scale. Failure to maintain these relationships, or successfully optimize our economies of scale in the future, could lead to higher unit costs for our procurement and present availability issues due to shortages of material or components such as microchips. As we do not manufacture any of the products that we rent to our customers, we rely on third-party suppliers for the provision of the equipment, tools, spare parts and consumables that are essential to our business. However, our suppliers may not be able to fulfill the terms of their agreements with us on a timely basis or at all for logistical or strategic reasons, including issues affecting the global supply chain generally as a result of economic disruption. Further, suppliers may be unwilling to extend contracts that provide favorable terms to us, or they may seek to renegotiate existing contracts with us. As a result, we could face increased costs for our equipment or longer delivery times. Delays in the delivery of new equipment may impair our ability to respond to increases in demand, put us at a disadvantage to our competitors and may cause us to miss opportunities in our markets. For instance, equipment manufacturers have recently faced and continue to face supply chain difficulties, in particular with respect to the raw materials needed to manufacture chips and batteries, and as a result, we have recently experienced, and continue to experience, delays in deliveries of purchased equipment. In addition, delays in delivery can adversely affect our equipment maintenance and relocation costs, as there may no longer be local demand for the purchased equipment by the time it arrives at the point of delivery. We may experience further delays or an inability to source new equipment on a timely basis or at all. We may not be able to find alternative sources of supply for the equipment we purchase in each of our core product categories, and the termination or delay of equipment orders by a major supplier could adversely affect our business. If we are required to procure more costly equipment, our business could be adversely affected if we are not able to pass the cost increases of such equipment through to our customers. Furthermore, while our top 10 suppliers at Group level only represented approximately 11.1% of our total expenditure for the year ended December 31, 2022, our procurement processes could be negatively affected if our business relationships with any of our top 10 suppliers are disrupted, which, in turn, could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows. ----- Any of the above factors could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

Subsubsection Title: The cost of equipment purchases for our rental fleet, in addition to other operating costs, may increase.
Subsubsection Text: The cost of new equipment that we purchase for our rental fleet may increase as a result of a number of factors, including increased raw material costs (such as costs of steel), scarcity of component parts necessary to manufacture our rental equipment (such as microchips and batteries), increased labor costs, inflation generally or geopolitical developments and other world events. For example, the Russian invasion of Ukraine destabilized the financial and commodity markets and resulted in an uncertain macroeconomic situation in Europe, causing inflation throughout the economy, rises in interest rates and volatile energy prices and such factors have had, and could have in the future, an adverse effect on the cost of new equipment we purchase for our rental fleet. In particular, the cost of steel, which is a primary material used in most of our equipment and products, rose sharply in 2021 as countries around the world began to recover from the economic downturn caused by COVID-19 and has continued to rise following the commencement of hostilities between Russia and Ukraine due to a combination of sanctions against Russian producers and disruptions of production in Ukraine. While additional capacity currently exists that can replace the foregoing volumes, increases in the spot prices of steel in Europe may nonetheless persist. Further increases in prices of raw materials could cause the price of new equipment to rise, which could materially affect our business to the extent that we are not able to pass such cost increases through to our customers. In addition, we are subject to risks related to the increases in energy or transportation costs. Energy prices are in turn subject to significant volatility caused by, among other things, inflation, market fluctuations, supply and demand, currency fluctuations, production and transportation disruptions, tariffs, resource availability, geopolitical developments and other world events, as well as climate change related conditions and other factors beyond our control. High energy and transportation costs could increase the price of new equipment purchases, which could adversely affect our business. Additionally, higher energy and transportation costs could significantly increase our operating costs. In 2022, partially as a result of the increase in fuel prices stemming from the conflict in Ukraine, we saw a significant increase in our logistics costs compared to prior years. There can be no assurance that we will be successful in minimizing our logistics costs through our hub-and-spoke logistics model or in passing along such costs to our customers. Any future increases in our logistics costs could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of operation and cash flows. Changes in customer demand due to changed technology, safety or environmental concerns, regulations, or other factors could cause certain of our existing equipment to become obsolete and require us to purchase new equipment, which would increase our costs. Further, electric, hybrid and battery powered equipment each have a purchasing cost which is significantly higher than similar equipment using older and less environmentally friendly engines. Purchasing electric, hybrid and battery powered equipment also incurs costs associated with training our employees and customers on the use, maintenance, safety requirements, and repair of the new technology. Due to the significantly higher purchasing costs of electric, hybrid and battery powered equipment our capital expenditure is expected to increase in the future. There can be no assurances that potential maintenance costs savings will offset the expected increase in capital expenditure. These factors in turn could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

Subsubsection Title: The effective management, maintenance and repair of our rental fleet is vital to our business.
Subsubsection Text: Our rental equipment has a long economic life, and managing this equipment is a critical element to our rental business. Rental equipment asset management requires that we build up and maintain an inventory of durable, high-quality products that anticipate the needs of our customers and changes in technology, legislation, regulations, building codes and local permitting in the various markets in which we operate. In addition, we must successfully maintain and repair this equipment cost-effectively to maximize the economic life of the products and, to a lesser extent, the proceeds that may be received from the sale of these products. As the needs of our customers change, we may need to incur costs to relocate or retrofit our rental assets to better meet shifts in demand, beyond relocations that occur in the ordinary course of business to maximize fleet uptime and address customer demand. In addition, if the location of our assets is not efficiently coordinated with regional demand, we may incur costs from relocating the fleet (which includes costs associated with local regulatory compliance, as well as transportation and storage) or we may be unable to take advantage of business opportunities despite excess inventory in other regions. If we are not able to successfully manage our rental assets, our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows could be materially adversely affected. In addition, where we have contracts that employ the use of our rental equipment for long durations, we may be exposed to the risk that our costs increase materially over the term of the project, whether due to inflation, rising interest rates or adverse movements in currency exchange rates, and we are unable to pass on those cost increases to such customers where fixed pricing has been agreed. If the project is significant (or if there are one or more issues that impact multiple projects) or experiences cost overruns, delays or issues with the quality or availability of supplies, any of these may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows. ----- As the equipment in our rental fleet ages, the cost of maintaining such equipment, if not replaced within a certain period of time, generally increases, and we may be unable to pass along such costs to customers. Determining the optimal average age for disposal of our rental fleet is subjective and requires considerable estimates by management. Additionally, maintenance of newer, electric and hybrid equipment may be costlier than the maintenance cost of older gas- and dieselpowered equipment, which could adversely affect our business if we are unable to pass those costs through to our customers. Our future operating results could be adversely affected because our maintenance and repair costs may be higher than estimated, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

Subsubsection Title: We are dependent on our executives, managers and employees.
Subsubsection Text: Our success depends, to a large degree, upon the continued effort and abilities of our existing management team, including our CEO and principal ultimate shareholder, Mr. Pierre Boels Jr. Our senior management team has significant experience in the industries and markets in which we operate. If we lose the services of any key member of our senior management team and are unable to find a suitable replacement in a timely manner, it may be a challenge for us to effectively manage our business and execute our strategy. Our success also depends on the experience and skills of our country and operational managers, district and area managers and depot managers, who have extensive knowledge of our business and industry experience. Competition for managers within our industry is generally significant, and, if any of our senior or regional managers joins a competitor or forms a competing company, we may lose customers, know-how and other personnel. In addition, we depend upon the quality of our staff personnel, including sales and customer service personnel who routinely interact with and fulfill the needs of our customers. There can be no assurance that we will be able to continue to attract, hire, train and retain qualified personnel, especially in the tight labor markets we currently face in most of the countries in which we operate or that we will not face increases in personnel expenses in line with, or above, inflation. A significant increase in personnel turnover or costs could negatively affect our results of operations and financial performance. Any of the above factors could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

Subsubsection Title: Damage to our reputation and our brand could adversely affect our business.
Subsubsection Text: We believe that we have developed a reputation and brand images associated with a high-quality fleet of rental equipment, customer service, reliability and social and environmental responsibility. Our brand names, trademarks and logos, as well as their respective reputation are valuable and powerful sales and marketing tools. Litigation, employee misconduct or the misconduct of anyone associated with the Boels brand (or any of our other brands), operational failures, accidents, the outcome of regulatory investigations, press speculation and negative publicity, disclosure of customer information, inadequate products and services, among others, could all affect our brand or reputation. Although our customers are generally responsible for the way in which they handle our rental equipment and despite our efforts to promote training and safety, accidents involving our equipment can and do occur, which can have an impact on the perceived image of our brands. Furthermore, the Boels brand is perceived to be strongly connected to our CEO, Pierre Boels Jr. and his family. Should Pierre Boels Jr. and his family cease to be connected to the Boels brand, for example, through exiting the business, our customer goodwill related to the Boels brand may decline. We are also exposed to the risk that individuals associated with the Boels brand (or any of our other brands) take actions that may affect our brand or reputation. The occurrence of any of the above risks could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

Subsubsection Title: Disruptions in our information technology systems could limit our capacity to effectively monitor and control our operations.
Subsubsection Text: We rely on information technology systems to track and bill our services, manage our fleet, meet our customers' needs and gather information upon which our management makes decisions regarding our business. Our information technology systems also facilitate our ability to adjust to changing market conditions. The administration of our business is increasingly reliant on the use of IT systems and artificial intelligence to digitalize processes and systems. The risk of a security breach or disruption, particularly through a cyber-attack or cyber intrusion, has risen as the number, intensity and sophistication of attempted attacks and intrusions around the world have increased. Additionally, due to the significant efforts to digitalize our business, an increasingly larger amount of data is stored in IT systems and vulnerable to data security breaches. Our information technology systems may not be fully protected against such third-party intrusions or against viruses, ransom ware, or similar threats. Disruptions resulting from these threats, system crashes or other causes could have a material adverse effect on our business. In particular, we use several ERP systems across our network and any disruption to our ERP systems, or the failure of any of these systems to operate as expected could, depending on the magnitude of the problem, adversely affect our operating results. We back-up most of our data daily, train our employees in this regard, perform penetration testing and have a disaster recovery plan in place for most of our systems, including our ----- ERP system. However, our disaster recovery plan does not cover all of our systems. Our back-up systems may fail, and any recovery of our data may be incomplete or subject to delay.
