The preparation of our consolidated financial statements requires management to make judgements, estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of revenues, expenses, assets and liabilities, and the accompanying disclosures, at the end of the reporting period. These estimates and judgements are subject to change based on experience and new information. The financial statement areas that required significant estimates, judgments and assumptions in the preparation of our consolidated financial statements are summarized in notes 2.4 and 3 to the HY 2023 Interim Financial Statements, notes 2.4 and 3 to the FY 2022 Financial Statements, notes 1.7, 2 and 3 to the FY 2021 Financial Statements and notes 1.8, 2 and 3 to the FY 2020 Financial Statements.

Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risks
Subsubsection Text: We are exposed to market risk mainly as a result of financial instruments denominated in a foreign currency (foreign currency risk) and our exposure to interest bearing liabilities such as loans (interest rate risk). _Foreign currency risk_ Foreign currency risk is the risk that the fair value of future cash flows will fluctuate because of changes in foreign exchange rates. Our exposure to the risk of changes in foreign exchange rates relates primarily to our operating activities (when revenue or expenses and their resulting receivable/payable positions are denominated in a foreign currency). The majority of our revenue (66.6% for the year ended December 31, 2022), expenses and obligations are denominated in euro. However, we are exposed to currency risk mainly from our cash flows generated in Sweden, Norway, the United Kingdom, Poland and the Czech Republic. We also incur currency risk on the net investment in our operations in Sweden, Poland, Hungary, Czech Republic, Switzerland, Denmark, Norway and the United Kingdom. Our management has determined, based on a risk assessment, to hedge some of these currency risks by using certain forward-exchange contracts. This policy is intended to protect our financial position. For additional information on foreign currency risk and our foreign exchange contracts, see note 7 to the HY 2023 Interim Financial Statements, note 28 to the FY 2022 Financial Statements, note 4 to the FY 2021 Financial Statements and note 4 to the FY 2020 Financial Statements. _Interest rate risk_ We are exposed to interest rate risk because entities in the Group borrow funds at both fixed and floating interest rates. Our policy is to have a fixed/floating interest rate profile on the interest bearing liabilities which is fitting with the nature of our assets. Hedging activities are evaluated regularly to align with our hedging policy. As most of the interest bearing liabilities have a floating interest rate, we have contracted certain interest rate swaps so that we receive floating interest and pay fixed interest. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, approximately 69% of the outstanding principal amount of our Existing Term Loan B was hedged through February 2028 with €1,000 million in nominal amount of interest rate swaps outstanding. For additional information on interest rate risk and our interest rate swaps, see note 7 to the HY 2023 Interim Financial Statements, note 28 to the FY 2022 Financial Statements, note 4 to the FY 2021 Financial Statements and note 4 to the FY 2020 Financial Statements.

Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risks
Subsubsection Text: Credit risk is the risk that we face when a customer or counterparty to a financial instrument fails to meet its contractual obligations. Credit risk mainly arises on cash and cash equivalents and receivable balances from trade and other receivables and other longer-term receivables. As of June 30, 2023, amounts exposed to credit risk include non-current loans receivable amounting to €9,840 million, trade receivables amounting to €227.4 million, other receivables amounting to €38.8 million and cash and cash equivalents amounting to €1.1 million. As of December 31, 2022, amounts exposed to credit risk include non-current loans receivable amounting to €2.5 million, trade receivables amounting to €210.4 million, other receivables amounting to €31.1 million and cash and cash equivalents amounting to €17.2 million. Substantially all of our cash at banks is held with high credit quality financial institutions with credit ratings of A(S&P) or higher. As of June 30, 2023, no significant increase in credit risk has occurred with respect to the above noted non-current loans receivable. The expected credit losses for these balances were computed based on a 12-month expected credit loss and was estimated to be remote. For additional information on credit risk, see note 7 to the HY 2023 Interim Financial Statements, note 28 to the FY 2022 Financial Statements.

Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risks
Subsubsection Text: Liquidity risk is the risk that we encounter difficulty in meeting our financial liabilities that are settled by delivering cash or another financial asset. Our approach to managing liquidity is to ensure, as far as possible, that we will meet our liabilities when they are due, under both normal and stressed conditions, without incurring unacceptable losses or risking damage to our reputation. We manage our liquidity risk by maintaining sufficient cash and available credit facilities through the continuous monitoring of future and actual cash flows and by matching the maturity profiles of our financial assets and liabilities. For additional information, see note 7 to the HY 2023 Interim Financial Statements, note 28 to the FY 2022 Financial Statements, note 4 to the FY 2021 Financial Statements and note 4 to the FY 2020 Financial Statements. -----

Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risks
Subsubsection Text: We are exposed to various market and financial risks, including foreign currency risk, interest rate risk, credit risk and liquidity risk. These risks and the manner in which we seek to mitigate them are summarized below and described in more detail in note 7 to the HY 2023 Interim Financial Statements, note 28 to the FY 2022 Financial Statements, note 4 to the FY 2021 Financial Statements and note 4 to the FY 2020 Financial Statements. -----

Subsection Title: Certain Differences Between Dutch GAAP and IFRS
Subsubsection Text: The following reconciliation of our statement of profit or loss and statement of cash flows for the year ended December 31, 2020 between Dutch GAAP and the Reconciled Financial Information has been prepared by management to aid in the understanding of our financial information on a more comparable basis with our financial information for subsequent periods prepared in accordance with IFRS. The adjustments to the FY 2020 Financial Statements prepared in accordance with Dutch GAAP to present the Reconciled Financial Information have been prepared on a basis that our management believes is consistent in all material respects as the basis on which our consolidated financial information is prepared in accordance with IFRS. However, the presentation of the Reconciled Financial Information is based on certain management assumptions and estimates, has been prepared for illustrative purposes only and, because of its nature, the Reconciled Financial Information addresses a hypothetical situation and, therefore, does not represent and may not give a true picture of our results for the year ended December 31, 2020 if we had prepared audited financial statements in accordance with IFRS for such period. For example, the Reconciled Financial Information has not retrospectively applied the IFRS requirements for business combinations as of January 1, 2020. Additional information on the basis of preparation of the Reconciled Financial Information is set out below. - The Reconciled Financial Information has been prepared based on the audited FY 2020 Financial Statements prepared in accordance with Dutch GAAP. - Certain line items have been reclassified from the FY 2020 Financial Statements to conform to IFRS presentation requirements. For further information, see "—Line Item Classification" below. ----- - Adjustments have been made based on the IFRS adjustments made in 2021 and 2022. For further information, see "—Notes to the Reconciled Financial Information" below. The Reconciled Financial Information is unaudited, is not fully comparable with our financial information for subsequent periods and should not be regarded as a substitute for our FY 2020 Financial Statements prepared in accordance with Dutch GAAP. See also "Risk Factors—Financial Risks—Our current financial statements are prepared in accordance _with IFRS and are not comparable with our prior financial statements prepared in accordance with Dutch GAAP."_ The following table sets forth a reconciliation of our statement of profit or loss between Dutch GAAP and the Reconciled Financial Information.

Subsection Title: Certain Differences Between Dutch GAAP and IFRS
Subsubsection Text: The FY 2021 Financial Statements and FY 2020 Financial Statements included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum have been prepared in accordance with Dutch GAAP. The FY 2022 Financial Statements and HY 2023 Interim Financial Statements included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum were prepared in accordance with IFRS. Certain differences exist between Dutch GAAP and IFRS that may be material to the financial information presented therein. The discussion set forth below summarizes certain differences identified between Dutch GAAP and IFRS as applied by the Group, following a limited analysis of both sets of principles. For additional information on our first-time adoption of IFRS, including reconciliations of certain financial information from Dutch GAAP to IFRS for the years ended December 31, 2021 and 2022, see note 30 to the FY 2022 Financial Statements. For a management reconciliation of our financial statements as of and for the year ended December 31, 2020 from Dutch GAAP to a more comparable basis with our financial information for subsequent periods prepared in accordance with IFRS, see "—Reconciled Financial _Information" below. See also "—Presentation of Financial Information" and "—Factors Affecting the Comparability of our Results of Operations—Application of IFRS" above._ Prospective investors are advised to consult their professional advisors for an understanding of: (i) the differences between Dutch GAAP, IFRS and other systems of generally accepted accounting principles and how those differences might affect the financial information included in this Offering Memorandum; and (ii) the impact that future additions to, or amendments of, IFRS may have on the financial information presented in this Offering Memorandum, our results of operations and/or financial condition, as well as on the comparability of prior periods. See also "Risk Factors—Financial _Risks—Our current financial statements are prepared in accordance with IFRS and are not comparable with our prior financial statements prepared in accordance with Dutch GAAP."_ Some key differences between Dutch GAAP and IFRS, as they relate to the Group, are listed hereafter. For additional information, see note 30 to the FY 2022 Financial Statements. - **Goodwill: Under Dutch GAAP, goodwill was capitalized and amortized on a straight-line basis. Goodwill under IFRS is required to be capitalized, however, no amortization thereof takes place. As a result, we have reversed €46.5 million of goodwill amortization in 2021. See "—Reconciled Financial _Information" below for information on the adjustments made for the Reconciled Financial Information_ for 2020. - **Leases: Under IFRS all leases are recognized in the balance sheet except for short term or low value lease contracts. Under Dutch GAAP financial lease contracts are presented "on-balance" and the operational lease contracts are presented "off-balance". On the transition date (January 1, 2021), we recognized €186.7 million of right of use assets and in total €183.9 million of lease liabilities. See "— _Reconciled Financial Information" below for information on the adjustments made for the Reconciled_ Financial Information for 2020.

Subsubsection Text: (1) See "—Notes to the Reconciled Financial Information" below. (2) Certain line items have been reclassified from the FY 2020 Financial Statements to conform to IFRS presentation requirements. For further information, see "—Line Item Classification" below. _Notes to the Reconciled Financial Information_ A. Goodwill Under Dutch GAAP, goodwill is capitalized and amortized on a straight-line basis. Goodwill under IFRS is required to be capitalized, however, no amortization thereof takes place. The amortization for the period presented has therefore been reversed within profit or loss. The impact is a reversal of €46.7 million amortization for the year ended December 31, 2020 presented under depreciation and amortization expenses. B. Leases At the date of transition to IFRS on January 1, 2021, we applied a single recognition and measurement approach for all leases except for low-value asset leases and short-term leases (twelve months or less). As we started accounting under IFRS as of January 1, 2021 for our entities in the Netherlands, we did not have the IFRS 16 accounting tools in place in 2020. In the Nordics (entities acquired in our acquisition of Cramo), IFRS 16 accounting tools were in place in 2020. As a result, for those countries where IFRS 16 accounting tools were not in place in 2020, we have made estimations based on the actual lease expenses in 2020 and the Right of Use starting point at January 1, 2021. The total impact on the profit and loss statement for the ended December 31, 2020 amounts to: - depreciation of right-of-use assets presented under depreciation and amortization expenses of €53.6 million were recognized in 2020; - lease expenses presented under material and services of €55.3 million were reversed in 2020; - lease liabilities interest expenses of €5.3 million presented under finance expense were recognized in 2020; and - the recognition of €0.3 million of revenue of subleases of real estate in 2020 which was presented under revenue. ----- C. Trade and other receivables The adoption of IFRS fundamentally changed our accounting for impairment losses for financial assets by replacing the incurred loss approach under Dutch GAAP with a forward-looking expected credit loss ("ECL") approach. IFRS requires us to recognize an allowance for ECLs for all financial asset debt instruments not held at fair value through profit or loss and contract assets. We assessed the impact of the change on transition date of January 1, 2021 to be recognized in the statement of profit or loss for 2020 which has led to a decrease in net impairment losses on financial assets in an amount of €1.2 million. D. Revenue Under Dutch GAAP, sales made through the DIY partner business are recognized on a net (agent) basis. The application of IFRS 15 to these contracts has resulted in the recognition of revenue on a gross (principal) basis and accordingly an increase in revenue was recognized in the 2020 financial year. We adjusted this by an increase of revenue of €8.5 million and an equivalent decrease in material and services. We also adjusted revenue by €0.3 million for revenue of subleases of real estate in 2020. See "—B. Leases" above. E. Deferred tax The various transitional adjustments (leases, trade and other receivables) results in different temporary differences. Deferred tax adjustments are recognized in correlation to the underlying transaction in income tax expense. The total adjustment amounts to €0.3 million additional tax expenses in 2020. F. Defined benefit obligations Defined benefit plan obligations are recognized and measured using the projected unit credit method (IAS19). The pension expenses in 2020 related to defined benefit plans, which amounted to €0.8 million. This has been adjusted under employee benefits expenses. G. Statement of cash flows Cash flows arising from payments of the principal portion of lease liabilities are classified as cash outflows from financing activities. Therefore, cash inflows from operating activities increased by €50.1 million and cash outflows from financing activities increased by the same amount for the year ended December 31, 2020. _Line Item Classification_ Certain line items have been reclassified from the FY 2020 Financial Statements for purposes of the 2020 comparative financial information presented in the FY 2021 Financial Statements. Certain of these line items have been reclassified in this Offering Memorandum to conform to IFRS presentation requirements. The following tables set forth the consolidated statement of profit or loss and consolidated statement of cash flows in accordance with the FY 2020 Financial Statements prepared in accordance with Dutch GAAP and the 2020 comparative financial information included in the FY 2021 Financial Statements prepared in accordance with Dutch GAAP, including certain information with respect to the reclassification of line items to the presentation shown under "—Reconciled Financial Information" above. For detail on our definition of Reported EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA, see "Summary Consolidated Financial _and Other Information—Summary Non-IFRS Measures and As Adjusted Financial Information" and "Presentation of Financial Information—Non-IFRS Measures."_

The equipment rental industry plays a key role in the value chain of significant and economically important endmarkets, including maintenance, infrastructure, construction, energy and energy transition as well as consumer-facing sectors. Equipment rental companies provide customers with a range for products from larger equipment such as aerial work platforms, excavators, earthmoving equipment and forklift trucks, to smaller equipment such as power saws, power generators, scaffolding, ladders, and small pumps. Rental companies are also active in rental markets for containers, sanitation, portable kitchens and trailers. In addition to providing equipment, many rental companies provide holistic support for their customers through a range of services such as maintenance, in-service inspection, repair, transportation, storage, compliance with health and safety regulations, insurance and training on the proper use of the equipment. The provision of holistic support along with equipment rental is becoming increasingly important for rental companies as large end-customers incrementally outsource those previously in-house services. Primary customers typically include engineering, procurement, and construction ("EPC") contractors, industrial companies, government entities, infrastructure facilitators, utilities, maintenance operators, construction companies as well as homeowners, craftsmen and small and medium-sized enterprises. A large portion of the equipment rental customer base comes from the industrial and the commercial construction sectors. Commercial construction rentals are geared towards contractors conducting new-build and repair and renovation work who rent a wide range of equipment from power tools to backhoes. Industrial rentals are geared towards businesses conducting routine plant maintenance as well as for projects that require specialized tools such as welding equipment, power washing equipment, forklifts and other material handling equipment. Additionally, craftsmen as well as events and media companies have increasingly relied on rental solutions for operational equipment such as power generators, portable toilets and specialized craft equipment. In parallel, specialized rental equipment are supplied for specific projects, such as transfer pump, site hut, security gate, site safe and industrial lighting. Increasingly, rental equipment are also requested in connection with the response to emergency situations and incidents, such as natural disasters and refugee crises. We operate depots in 18 countries with our key geographic markets being Germany, the Netherlands, Sweden, Finland and Belgium. The dynamics of the customer and geographic end markets we serve vary significantly, as described below under "—Our Key Geographic Markets."

Subsection Title: Customer Value Proposition and Equipment Rental Business Model
Subsubsection Text: The long-term growth prospects for the equipment rental industry continue to be favorable, supported by fundamental tailwinds as customers are increasingly renting (i.e., outsourcing) rather than owning operational equipment. The shift to outsourcing is also driven by structural macroeconomic and regulatory factors that increase the attractiveness of renting equipment. The advantages of equipment rental over ownership for companies includes: - **Cost and business flexibility: Equipment rental increases business flexibility by allowing companies to transform fixed costs into variable costs incurred on an as needed basis. In contrast, equipment ownership entails a higher proportion of fixed costs and includes a number of ongoing costs in addition to the cost of initial purchase, such as insurance, maintenance, in service inspection, repair, transportation and storage and depreciation costs, which tend to increase over the life of the equipment. Equipment rental also reduces the amount of capital required in comparison to purchasing equipment, reducing a customer's exposure to credit market conditions and preserving capital for other investments, all of which enables customers to focus on the core parts of their business. - **Equipment access and availability: Equipment rental gives customers access to a comprehensive range of equipment, including the latest generation of technology, allowing them to select the most appropriate piece of equipment for the task at hand, which can improve safety, efficiency and quality. Equipment rental also allows customers to benefit from a number of ancillary services provided by rental companies, including training, safety testing, regulatory compliance, logistical support and consultation on equipment selection. In addition, when renting from rental companies with a large network of branches, customers are able to optimize their logistics flows to and from their worksites. ----- - **Climate change awareness: Rental of equipment is part of the larger developing circular economy, where equipment is rented by many customers over its life cycle allowing for better utilization rates while the rental company maintains control over the equipment's good functioning order through a program of maintenance and regular inspections. Equipment rental allows customers to be a part of this circular economy and reduce their carbon emissions by reducing the overall size of their equipment fleet, limiting their carbon footprint to the use of such equipment only and utilizing newer and more sustainable equipment compared with company-owned equipment. - **Health and safety: Equipment rental generally enhances the operational safety of customers by providing modern, well-serviced equipment. In addition, equipment rental allows customers to more easily benefit from the mechanization and automation of many of their operations, including hazardous tasks, by providing access to and training on specialized equipment, such as power access tools. In the European rental market, the key performance criteria mentioned by rental equipment customers consist of the availability of equipment, equipment quality, location, flexibility, and safety, which can be more important than price in certain markets. Small and medium enterprises ("SME") tend to place orders via sales representatives or through direct engagement with a depot representative, while medium to large companies are increasingly ordering through online platforms. On average, a majority of rental equipment clients use two or more equipment rental companies primarily as a result of assortment, availability and price differences for each product segment. The economic value-add of a rental equipment provider is derived from the benefit from a lower break-even period and enhanced returns compared to regular equipment purchasers as a result of more efficient fleet utilization, benefit from centralized procurement contracts resulting in lower purchase prices, centralized and lower annual repair and maintenance costs, benefit from higher resale value after the useful life and equipment financing benefits due to economies of scale.
The following chart sets forth certain information with respect to the estimated market size of each of our markets in 2022 based on the ERA 2022 Market Report.

GDP growth and construction market activity levels Growth in the equipment rental industry tends to be closely correlated to growth in the construction market, as the equipment rental industry generally forecasts growth levels in the construction market and responds to changing demand related thereto. The construction market is composed of three primary subsectors: (i) new residential and non-residential building, (ii) renovation and maintenance, and (iii) infrastructure (which includes transportation infrastructure and telecommunications, as well as energy and water works). While the construction industry as a whole tends to be cyclical, within the overall construction market, individual end markets have differentiated growth patterns and dynamics. For example, the renovation and maintenance end market tends to be less cyclical, as customers tend to reduce or delay new projects in favor of renovation and maintenance work during periods of economic downturns. In addition, construction activity can vary significantly between different regional and local markets, which provides further balance and diversification to demand for rental equipment. In 2022, a majority of the largest European construction markets surveyed by Euroconstruct registered higher than anticipated growth at 3%, within an overall expansionary economic environment. The outlook for the overall European construction market is trending lower in 2023 and 2024, mainly due to a slowdown in the residential sector, with return to growth expected as soon as 2025. However, the maintenance and renovation sectors are expected to grow over the same period due to increase driven by sustainability regulations and energy efficiency measures in a context of high energy prices. This resonates with the recent European Green Deal proposals, with one of the main priorities revolving around ----- renovation, energy efficiency and cleaner energy. This is further supported by local government regulations, notably in the Netherlands' renovation and infrastructure maintenance markets. We have a proven track record of minimizing the impact of economic trends on our business by diversifying our specialist activities across non-construction related niche markets and focusing on the less cyclical phases of construction market, such as the fit out, maintain, and operation phases. We also operate in multiple end markets in various countries, which enhances our resilience and reduces our exposure to market volatility, macroeconomic developments and specific events. Approximately 54% of our sales for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023 come from non-construction customers, indicating relatively modest exposure to the construction sector's cyclical volatility. Furthermore, our exposure to the construction end-market includes a large part of less cyclical businesses such as fit out, maintain and operation, which account for more than half of the construction-related sales. Urbanization Urbanization is a key driver of demand for rental services, as the population shift towards cities increases the need for infrastructure development and maintenance. This leads to higher expenditures on large infrastructure projects, which typically require a wide range of equipment and tools that are more cost-effective and convenient to rent than to buy.

The European rental market has experienced a steady increase in its rental penetration rate over the past years, reflecting the growing preference of customers to rent rather than buy equipment and tools. The rental penetration rate varies across countries, with Germany, the Netherlands, Sweden, Belgium, Ireland, France, Denmark and the UK being relatively the most mature markets, and Eastern European countries having lower rental penetration rates, which offer significant growth potential. Increased benefits of rental versus ownership One of the key drivers for the increase in rental penetration rates is the enhanced value proposition of renting compared to owning equipment. Renting equipment offers access to modern equipment, flexibility, and cost-efficiency, as it reduces capital expenditure requirements, fixed costs of ownership, and residual value risk, while allowing customers to adapt to changing demand and project requirements. Moreover, large rental companies can leverage their scale and expertise in purchasing, maintenance, and repair of equipment, offering a competitive advantage over smaller companies that lack the financial resources for large fleet investments. Renting equipment also becomes more attractive for customers in an uncertain or declining economic environment, as customers in general prefer to opt for flexibility and avoid the burden of ownership and opt for more flexible and variable solutions. Decarbonization and ESG initiatives Another key driver for the increase in rental penetration rates is the growing pressure to decarbonize and adopt ESG initiatives across various industries. Renting equipment is inherently part of the circular economy, as it maximizes the utilization and lifespan of equipment, while ensuring its proper functioning and safety through regular maintenance and inspections. Renting also reduces the operational complexity and waste associated with owning equipment, as it requires fewer procurement, logistics, and disposal activities, while optimizing the carbon footprint. For instance, the building and construction industry, which is a significant contributor to global carbon emissions, can benefit from renting more energyefficient and ESG-friendly equipment from rental companies. As market participants require more energy efficient and sustainable equipment, they are expected to rely more heavily on rental companies to provide the latest generation of equipment. Growing demand for digital solutions and add-on services Rental penetration rates are expected to be driven by the rising demand for digital solutions and add-on services that complement and enhance the rental offer and customer experience. Digitalization and technological advances enable rental companies to provide more value-added services, such as fleet management, route optimization, environmental reporting, online ordering and billing, which increase efficiency, transparency, and convenience for customers. Customers also expect more instant and easy access to information and offerings, price comparison, and online reviews, which rental companies can leverage to differentiate themselves and build loyalty. We have invested heavily in our digital capabilities and platforms to offer a seamless and customer-centric service across our markets and segments. Increasing preference for end-to-end proposition Growth in rental penetration rates is also expected to be driven by changing customer preferences for end-to-end propositions that provide turnkey solutions for their broader needs and project success, rather than just equipment or ----- services for specific tasks. Customers seek more comprehensive and integrated solutions that cover the entire value chain and offer a degree of flexibility and customization. Rental companies can respond to this demand by offering and providing packaged solutions that include a full range of equipment and services, such as planning, installation, operation, and maintenance that are tailored to the specific requirements and objectives of each customer and project. For example, we have provided full turnkey solutions for an automotive gigafactory in Berlin-Brandenburg by supplying a full range of equipment and services.

Boels presence Boels core geographies According to the ERA 2022 Market Report, the equipment rental market size for the 15 European countries covered by such report (representing Austria, Belgium, Czech Republic, Denmark, Germany, Finland, France, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Poland, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland and the UK, together "ERA Europe Countries") was estimated at €25.7 billion in 2022. The market is mainly centered in Western and Central Europe with smaller market sizes for Northern, Southern and Eastern Europe. The UK, Germany and France are the largest European markets for rental equipment with their combined share estimated at approximately 60% of the total market size. According to the ERA 2022 Market Report, the market is highly fragmented with approximately 58% of European rental market revenue generated by small firms, approximately 23% generated by middle-size companies and nearly 20% generated by large companies (defined as companies with more than 250 employees). According to the ERA 2022 Market Report the European rental market has seen strong growth between 2010 and estimates 2022 with a CAGR of 3.8%, which exceeds the average GDP growth of the 27 European countries over the same period. Following a contraction of 10.5% in 2020 (primarily driven by Covid-19), the European rental market grew by an |1,170|Col2| |---|---| ||885| ||| ----- estimated 7.9% in 2021 and 4.1% in 2022 and is forecast to grow by 3.3% in 2023 based on the ERA 2022 Market Report. The ERA June 2023 Strategic Report forecasts an increase in rental industry sales for each of the ERA Europe Countries between 2022 and 2024, with significant growth forecasted for Boels' main markets in the Netherlands (forecasted to grow by a CAGR of 3.2%), Germany (forecasted to grow by a CAGR of 3.7%), Belgium (forecasted to grow by a CAGR of more than 4.5%), Sweden (forecasted to grow by a CAGR of more than 2.3%) and Finland (forecasted to grow by a CAGR of 4.7%). The following chart sets forth the forecasted growth rate for each of our key markets based on the ERA June 2023 Strategic Report and our organic revenue growth in each market for 2021 and 2022. Source: 2021 and 2022 based on ERA 2022 Market Report; 2023 and 2024 based on the ERA June 2023 Strategic Report, except for information regarding Boels' growth in each country. Note: (1) In local currency. (2) Represents estimated organic growth in the Netherlands, excluding the Eekel Pompen contribution in 2022. Without the adjustment, reported growth amounted to 17.8%. (3) Represents estimated organic growth in Germany, excluding the termination of business in second quarter of 2020. Without the adjustment, reported growth amounted to +0.4%. The key growth drivers of the European rental market is a conjunction of both growth of the equipment rental market and increasing market penetration, as described further below.

The European equipment rental industry is highly fragmented, with a large number of small players serving local or regional markets, and a smaller number of medium-sized to large players serving regional, national and international customer bases. As a result, the industry has experienced a high degree of consolidation in recent years. For example, we have completed 27 acquisitions since 2012, including the transformational acquisition of Cramo in 2020. We believe we are the second largest equipment rental company in Europe based on revenue for 2022, as illustrated by the chart below. We compete primarily with large national and international equipment providers that offer broad, generalized product ranges to customers. These include Loxam/Ramirent, and Kiloutou, both of which have a strong presence in France. In contrast to our largest competitors which have a higher focus on heavy equipment required in the new building phases, our business model focuses more on lighter equipment used in the subsequent fit out, maintain and operate phase (post-heavy equipment phase), resulting in less cyclical end-markets with higher degree of flexibility in equipment allocation and utilization. Post-heavy construction phases tend to be more diverse in terms of workload and therefore provide a greater opportunity to differentiate the product and service offering, including potential for ongoing service elements. We believe we have strong market positions across our main markets. We believe we have the largest market share in each of the Netherlands, Belgium and Sweden in terms of revenue in 2022, with an estimated market share of 2530% in the Netherlands, in Belgium an estimated market share of approximately 10%, and an estimated market share of close to 20% in Sweden. We believe we have the second largest market share in Germany and Finland in terms of revenue in 2022, with an estimated market share of 5-10% in Germany and more than 15% in Finland. In addition, we believe we have a leading position in Norway with an estimated market share of 5-10%. The following chart provides certain information on our market position and the overall market size for each market based on the ERA 2022 Market Report. Source: ERA 2022 Market Report for market sizes. Market shares and market position are derived from Company estimates. Note: Chart excludes our presence in France and Denmark through our DIY business. (1) Market shares ranges based on our revenue for the year ended December 31, 2022 per country divided by the market size of the respective country for 2022 according to the ERA 2022 Market Report. (2) Company estimates based on our revenue for the year ended December 31, 2022 and publicly available information for local peers for the most recent year available. (3) Based on ERA 2022 Market Report. ----- The equipment rental market is characterized by competition among operators who seek to differentiate themselves on various factors including, the availability and quality of their equipment, the price and terms of their rental contracts, the strength and quality of their sales relationships, the speed and reliability of their delivery and service, and their adherence to health and safety standards. Despite the fragmentation of the equipment rental industry in Europe, the leading players benefit from significant advantages over smaller players or new entrants, which create substantial barriers to entry. These advantages stem from the large capital investments required to acquire and maintain a diverse and modern fleet of equipment as well as to establish and operate a network of depots close to the areas of high demand. Moreover, the largest equipment rental companies have built long-term and loyal relationships with key suppliers and customers, which enable them to secure preferential terms and access to equipment and projects. Additionally, they benefit from economies of scale, which allow them to optimize their costs and margins, and from strong brand positioning, which enhances their reputation and customer loyalty.

According to the ERA 2022 Market Report, the German rental market is expected to reach a total size of approximately €5.0 billion in 2022, an increase of approximately 2.0% compared to 2021, and based on the ERA June 2023 Strategic Report, is forecast to grow by approximately 4.3% in 2023 and 3.1% in 2024. Demand in the construction sector accounts for approximately 65% of the total market sales. The German rental industry, Europe's second largest market after France, is characterized by a fragmented and diversified competitive landscape consisting of a number of international and regional players with a strong local customer base. We believe we are the second largest player in the market, with an estimated 5-10% market share based on 2022 revenue, with the largest player, Zeppelin, mainly focused on earthmoving equipment. Other large players include, HKL and Mateco. Recently, foreign players including Kiloutou and Riwal entered the German market through acquisitions but are still relatively small. German customer demand tends to be sophisticated in terms of higher focus on innovation, service offering and quality, illustrated by an increasing demand for on-site services such as temporary traffic management, onsite power and water, safety management, and site access control. We believe we are well-positioned to benefit from these factors with our strong services, network density and fleet offering, which include a wide range of equipment, from small tools to large machines, as well as specialized solutions for specific sectors and projects. The growth potential in Germany is significant and is expected to be primarily driven by two factors: increasing penetration of rental equipment and fundamental growth in infrastructure and energy sector in the mid-to-long term. In particular, the infrastructure and energy sector is expected to benefit from strong demand for infrastructure projects, especially within highways and bridges, which require substantial maintenance and modernization. In addition, the energy sector is expected to provide further growth, particularly as coal energy production is set to end by 2037, which necessitates structural changes to Germany's current energy infrastructure, a trend which is also expected for other major European countries. Additional key trends in the German rental market that are expected to shape the industry dynamics and performance in the coming years include (i) further consolidation of the fragmented market, as larger players seek to gain scale and market share through acquisitions and partnerships, (ii) a focus on decarbonization of construction sites, leading to increased demand for newer and more efficient equipment, (iii) substantial government expenditures on large infrastructure projects, aimed at addressing a backlog of civil engineering projects (roads, bridges, rail) as well as investments in 5G infrastructure and energy transition as a result of policies to increase renewable energy sources, and (iv) increasing demand for one-stop-shop offering, over pure specialist rental companies, as customers seek to simplify their procurement processes and benefit from a broader range of equipment and services from a single provider. _The Netherlands_ The following table sets forth the market turnover growth rate for the Netherlands for the periods indicated. ----- The Netherlands ................................................ (5.6)% 3.7% 3.1% 2.4% 4.0% Source: 2021 and 2022 based on ERA 2022 Market Report; 2023 and 2024 based on the ERA June 2023 Strategic Report. The Dutch equipment rental market is a sizable and growing sector, with an estimated value of approximately €1.2 billion in turnover in 2022 according to the ERA 2022 Market Report. The market is forecast to grow at a rate of approximately 2.4% in 2023 and accelerate to approximately 4.0% in 2024 based on the ERA June 2023 Strategic Report. The growth prospects are supported by the ongoing and planned investment in various segments of infrastructure, environment, and new technologies, with a focus on enhancing energy efficiency and security in the country. The Dutch rental industry is characterized by a relatively high degree of consolidation, with a dominant player and a few large competitors, followed by a number of smaller and more specialized or local providers. We believe we are the market leader in the Dutch rental industry in terms of revenue in 2022, with an estimated market share of approximately 25-30%. Although not directly comparable, other large players in the market include Collé, Loxam, Mateco, Peinemann and Riwal. Smaller rental companies, with less than 50 employees, account for approximately 41% of the total market sales, reflecting the fragmentation of the market. Key trends in the Dutch rental market include: (i) consolidation, with smaller challengers being acquired by established players, (ii) increasing demand for DIY and rental of small equipment, driven by a growing number of independent craftsmen who prefer to rent rather than buy equipment for their projects, (iii) growing demand for digitalization of products and services offering, with currently low penetration of digital solutions as well as packaged services, (iv) increasing focus on emission and more hybrid solutions for rental equipment, due to stricter government regulations and environmental standards that require more energy-efficient and less polluting equipment, and (v) increase of maintenance and repair of infrastructure, with the recent Dutch government's announcement to address a number of repair issues in the existing roads and bridges. _Sweden_ The following table sets forth the market turnover growth rate for Sweden for the periods indicated. Sweden ................................................................. (4.2)% 2.5% 3.2% 1.0% 3.7% Source: 2021 and 2022 based on ERA 2022 Market Report; 2023 and 2024 based on the ERA June 2023 Strategic Report. According to the ERA 2022 Market Report, the Swedish rental market has an estimated value of SEK17.9 billion in turnover in 2022 and is forecast to grow by approximately 1.0% in 2023, accelerating to approximately 3.7% in 2024 based on the ERA June 2023 Strategic Report. Demand in the construction sector accounted for approximately 70% of the total market sales in 2022, according to the ERA 2022 Market Report. We believe we have the second largest market position in the Swedish rental industry in terms of revenue in 2022, with an estimated market share of close to 20%. Other major competitors include Ramirent/Loxam and Renta. Compared to other European countries, the Swedish rental market is mature and has a high rental penetration rate, meaning that a large proportion of construction equipment is rented rather than owned. In the medium to long term, the market is expected to benefit from the structural trends of public investment in greener iron, steel and battery production, as well as the shift to renewable power generation from wind and solar sources. Sweden has one of the highest rental GDP and construction sector penetration in Europe, as well as high standards for safety, quality, and environmental performance. Customers are increasingly demanding end-to-end rental solutions that cover not only the equipment, but also the ancillary services such as on-site traffic management, waste management, and safety solutions. Moreover, there is a strong demand for modern and safer machines that have a lower environmental footprint, as the market is moving towards decarbonization and sustainability. _Finland_ The following table sets forth the market turnover growth rate for Finland for the periods indicated. ----- Finland .................................................................. (5.1)% 2.3% 6.8% 5.2% 4.2% Source: 2021 and 2022 based on ERA 2022 Market Report; 2023 and 2024 based on the ERA June 2023 Strategic Report. According to the ERA 2022 Market Report, the Finnish equipment rental market has an estimated value of approximately €0.7 billion in turnover in 2022 and, based on the ERA June 2023 Strategic Report, is forecast to grow by approximately 5.2% in 2023 and 4.2% in 2024. Demand in the construction sector accounted for approximately 70% of the total market sales in 2022, according to the ERA 2022 Market Report. The construction market saw significant growth in 2022, reflecting positive developments in infrastructure and non-residential projects. The market outlook for the medium term is favorable, as the rental penetration rate and the outsourcing trend from ownership to rental are expected to increase further in the coming years. The competitive landscape of the Finnish rental market has historically been dominated by two local major players, Loxam/Ramirent and Boels/Cramo. However, the market has recently witnessed the emergence of Renta as a new player, driving up investments and increasing competition through consolidation with small players. The market is also characterized by a large number of smaller companies (with 1-49 employees), which generated approximately 63% of the total industry revenue, and large firms (with over 250 employees), which generated approximately 37% of total industry revenue according to the ERA 2022 Market Report. Merger and acquisition activity in the Finnish rental market has been relatively stable, especially compared to the neighboring markets of Norway and Sweden, which have seen more consolidation in recent years. The investment level in the market is high, as companies seek to renew their fleet and add more sustainable fleet options, as demand for equipment such as crane equipment and electric machinery increases. The demand for greener equipment is supported by investment from the public sector. Key trends that shape the Finnish rental market include: (i) a growing demand for add-on or packaged services, (ii) an increasing focus on digitalization with connected fleet and digital services, (iii) a rising focus on decarbonization and greener solutions following Finnish regulations aimed at reducing the emissions of the sector, and (iv) a geographical polarization, with construction and equipment rental market concentrated in the main urban areas. _Belgium_ The following table sets forth the market turnover growth rate for Belgium for the periods indicated. Belgium ................................................................ (8.8)% 3.7% 3.6% 4.1% 5.0% Source: 2021 and 2022 based on ERA 2022 Market Report; 2023 and 2024 based on the ERA June 2023 Strategic Report. According to the ERA 2022 Market Report, the Belgian equipment rental market has an estimated value of approximately €0.7 billion in turnover in 2022 and, based on the ERA June 2023 Strategic Report, is forecast to grow by approximately 4.1% in 2023 and 5.0% in 2024 as construction activity is projected to improve. The rental companies in Belgium have benefited from the strong recovery of the rental demand, which has resulted in full order books through mid-2023. As the rental volume growth normalizes in the medium term, increasing rental penetration rates are expected to drive further growth in the industry. The Belgian rental industry is characterized by a high level of fragmentation, whereby only a few rental companies have national coverage, caused by the regional split between Flanders and Wallonia and the related language differences. Generally, Flanders tends to have more specialized rental companies that are oriented towards the non-construction sector, while Wallonia tends to have more generalist rental companies that are focused on the construction sector. This is a distinctive feature of the Belgian market compared with other European markets (except for Switzerland) and has not significantly changed in the recent years. Given that most rental players are local rather than national, the language barrier increases the barriers to entry for new domestic or foreign players, as they need to adapt to the different customer needs in each region. We are one of the few players with nation-wide coverage in Belgium and we believe we have the largest market position in the Belgian rental industry in terms of revenue in 2022, with an estimated market share of approximately 10%. ----- Other large players in the market include Loxam and TVH. Small rental companies (less than 50 employees) contributed approximately 75% to the total market sales in Belgium in 2022, according to the ERA 2022 Market Report. According to the ERA 2022 Market Report, although investment levels were flat in 2022 compared to 2021, Belgian rental companies are renewing their fleet and adding new machinery as market demand is trending higher for smaller machines, access equipment and platforms. The transition to hybrid machinery or battery powered equipment has resulted in increased demand, but this is still slow and not expected to materialize meaningfully in the short-term. However, in the longer term, environmental regulations and customer awareness of environmental issues are expected to drive a more significant increase in demand. Additionally, outside the construction and industrial sectors, there has been a substantial increase in rental demand in the Belgian events sector. -----

We are a leading rental equipment specialist in Europe. We believe we are the second largest equipment rental company in Europe based on revenue for 2022, with strong market positions across our main markets, including the largest market share in each of the Netherlands, Belgium and Sweden and the second largest market share in each of Germany and Finland, in each case in terms of revenue in 2022. Our family-owned business started out of four garage boxes in the 1970s, and, under five decades later, has expanded into an industry leader with an extensive network of 759 depots in 18 European countries and a fleet of approximately 860,000 rental units as at June 30, 2023. In the twelve months ended June 30, 2023, we generated €1,524.9 million in revenue and €540.2 million in Adjusted EBITDA. We serve customers in a variety of end-markets from civil engineering, industrial, construction and infrastructure to events and warehousing. Our core product offering includes general and specialist rental equipment alongside complementary products and services, enabling us to be a one-stop-shop for our customer base of both corporate clients (business-to-business) and individuals including craftsmen and retail clients (business-to-consumer). Our generalist division is mainly focused on the less cyclical 'fit-out, maintain and operate' market segments which use lighter equipment, while our specialist division is tailored to reach niche markets, such as site preparation, sanitation and access control. With approximately 860,000 rental items, with a purchase value of €2.8 billion as of June 30, 2023, we offer our customers access to one of the largest, widest, highest quality, and latest ranges of rental equipment and tools in Europe, for use in the fields of civil engineering (such as excavators, landscaping tools and dumpers), transport and handling (such as forklifts, cranes and trailers), climate control (such as heating and cooling systems, mobile boilers and air purifiers), and construction (such as construction site and installation products), among others. In addition to our vast range of tools and equipment available in our general depots, we provide a wide range of specialist products to niche markets primarily outside the construction industry, which we believe differentiates us from our competition and contributes to our strong brand recognition and greater diversification in terms of end-markets and product offering. Our specialist products range from HVAC systems and hoisting and lifting machines to mobile LED screens, temporary housing solutions, portable kitchens and heavy duty pumps. In parallel, we offer "do-it-yourself" ("DIY") shop-in-shops across Europe, in partnership with DIY retailers where retail clients get access to primarily smaller equipment rental, which we believe further renders our business less cyclical than the traditional equipment rental business. Our corresponding service lines are geared towards further simplifying our customers' complex projects and include equipment service and maintenance, fuel management, training courses, project management and emergency assistance. In this Offering Memorandum, we present certain information for the following four geographic regions: - **_The Netherlands, which generated €362.9 million in revenue (representing 23.8% of our revenue) in the twelve months ended June 30, 2023; - **_Central Europe, consisting of Belgium, Germany, Austria, Hungary, Switzerland, Luxembourg, Poland, the Czech Republic and Slovakia, which generated €538.9 million in revenue (representing 35.3% of our revenue) in the twelve months ended June 30, 2023; - **_Northern Europe, consisting of Sweden, Norway, Finland, Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania, which generated €576.8 million in revenue (representing 37.8% of our revenue) in the twelve months ended June 30, 2023; and - **_Other Countries, consisting of Italy and the United Kingdom, which generated €46.4 million in revenue (representing 3.0% of our revenue) in the twelve months ended June 30, 2023. In addition, in six months ended June 30, 2023, we introduced segmental reporting in line with IFRS 8 "Operating Segments" for the first time. For additional information on our operating segments, see "Presentation of Financial _Information—Operating Segments."_ ----- We operate under two main brands: Boels Rental and Cramo. Boels Rental, the original brand of the Boels Group, is active in 12 countries in Central and Western Europe and we believe holds the strongest brand recognition across our portfolio. Cramo is active in the Nordic and the Baltic states, having been an independent leading rental company in Europe since 1953 before we acquired it in 2020. We operate a hub-and-spoke depot network, consisting of 681 general rental product depots and 78 specialist rental product depots as of June 30, 2023. We believe the decentralized structure of our network enables us to provide our products and services to our customers more conveniently and efficiently, while also supplying us with a diversified and local customer reach. In countries where we have an extensive depot network, such as the Netherlands and Germany, each depot is connected to a central hub location. In countries with larger markets, we have several hubs. Our depots generally stock smaller and more commonly used equipment, while the larger and less commonly used equipment is stored at our hubs, from where they can be easily shipped directly to a customer or local depot as needed. We believe this structure allows us to make more efficient use of our fleet and minimize transport movements. Through a combination of organic growth and strategic acquisitions, we have expanded significantly over the past decade, both in terms of geographical reach and product offering. Since Pierre Boels Jr. became the CEO of Boels in 1996, we have executed a growth strategy based on product portfolio diversification and greenfield openings (including through international expansion), as well as through strategic bolt-on acquisitions executed to enter specific geographic areas (such as Germany, the UK and the Nordics) or specialist markets (such as industrial rental and traffic service). In 2020, we acquired Cramo, which positioned us as one of the largest equipment rental companies in Europe and complemented our geographic presence with an expansion into the Nordics and a further extension of our Central European offering. In addition, our 2022 acquisition of Eekels Pompen allowed us to expand our specialist product line by adding a high-quality offering of pump rentals to our customers with niche needs. The sharing economy is at the very heart of our business, and we believe that long-term growth prospects for the equipment rental industry continue to be favorable, driven by increased consumer preferences for rental instead of ownership. From our perspective, renting provides our customers with optimal availability, accessibility, and capital deployment, enabling them to reduce the amount of capital required for their operations, and, in turn, increase their capacity to deploy it for other investments. As such, our rental concept aims to help customers and their end-consumers meet their targets in terms of costs, efficiency, quality and sustainability. We also believe that rental, compared to ownership, can contribute positively to the environment. Therefore, alongside the benefits that we strive to offer our customers, we also invest in products and solutions that align with our commitment to advancing sustainability in our and our customers' industries.

Subsubsection Title: Leading market positions in a large and growing European market supported by favorable underlying growth drivers
Subsubsection Text: We have grown significantly since our founding in 1977 as a local rental company. Since then, we have grown into a multinational company through a combination of organic growth and transformative and bolt-on acquisitions. With the Cramo acquisition in 2020, which allowed us to expand our operations in the Nordics and Baltics while strengthening our network in Western and Central Europe, we have created a true pan-European rental equipment player with increased scale and resilience. We believe that our current footprint provides us with beneficial scale in strong and growing geographic and customer end-markets. We believe we are the second largest equipment rental business in Europe by rental revenue in 2022. As of June 30, 2023, we operate a comprehensive depot network of 759 depots, comprising 681 general rental depots and 78 specialist rental depots. We believe that our scale is particularly important as a provider of rental equipment, because it helps us optimize fleet utilization rates through our ability to easily relocate units to areas with higher demand for specific types of equipment and provides us with additional bargaining power in negotiations with OEMs and equipment suppliers and maintenance partners. We believe that our scale and our market leadership also help to increase our brand recognition and affords us with greater opportunities to attract and retain talented and experienced personnel. In the Netherlands, which is historically our cornerstone market, we believe that we hold a strong leader position with between 25% and 30% of market share based on revenue in 2022, which we believe is significantly ahead of our competitors. We believe we are also the leader in Belgium with approximately 10% of market share and the second-largest player in Germany with between 5% and 10% of market share, in each case based on revenue in 2022. With the acquisition of Cramo in 2020, we expanded our presence into five more European markets (Sweden, Norway, Finland, Estonia and Lithuania) and significantly strengthened our position in six European countries where Boels and Cramo had a joint presence. We believe that we are the second largest player in Sweden, with close to 20% of market share, and in Finland, with more than 15% of market share, in each case based on revenue in 2022. ----- We believe that the markets we address are strong and poised for further growth. According to the ERA 2022 Market Report, the total market size of the top 15 European rental equipment markets is estimated to have increased by 4% from €24.7 billion in 2021 to €25.7 billion in 2022, and is forecasted to grow by 3.3% in 2023 and 5.6% in 2024. According to the ERA 2022 Market Report, the European market is expected to remain strong, driven by an increased rental penetration and a structural shift in customers' preferences towards renting rather than owning equipment. This shift is supported by the attractiveness and flexibility offered by renting, as it optimizes the split between operating costs and capital expenditures by reducing the fixed portion of maintenance and fleet replacement costs and allows customers to avoid investing in expensive equipment that may not be used frequently. Moreover, the transition to achieving net zero CO2 emissions amplifies this effect, as electric equipment is generally more expensive. This structural shift is expected to support continued demand for rental equipment companies' products and services over the medium and long term. We believe that we are well-positioned to benefit from growth and positive trends in the equipment rental industry. The European rental equipment industry is still highly fragmented, consisting of a large number of small companies serving local or regional markets, with a limited number of medium to larger companies serving regional, national and international customers. We believe we are one of only a few companies with a strong pan-European platform, with strong relationships with the key equipment OEMs. We compete with a large number of smaller competitors locally and a few larger international competitors. We believe that we are well-positioned for growth by leveraging our scale and footprint, while relying on our proven approach of customizing our strategy for each local market, while centralizing our key operations.

Subsubsection Title: Resilient business model supported by robust diversification across geographies, end markets, products and customers, supported by a notable depot network
Subsubsection Text: We strive to minimize the impact of economic cycles through continually maximizing our rental fleet utilization rate, developing specialist activities focused on non-construction related niche markets, diversifying our customer base by investing in a broad product range aimed at non-construction related customers and focusing on the less cyclical phases of construction projects. We have a diversified footprint and address several different customer end-markets, helping to mitigate our exposure to macroeconomic uncertainty. In particular, with the acquisition of Cramo, we significantly increased our geographical diversification, bringing our revenue generated in the Netherlands to 24% of our total revenue for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023, compared to nearly half of our total revenue for the year ended December 31, 2018. Moreover, no single country represented more than 25% of our revenue generation for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023. We believe that this enhanced geographic diversification gives us greater resilience during periods of slow economic growth, as different countries operate within different economic cycles. Based on our revenue and EBITDA growth, we believe we outperformed our largest European competitors during the COVID-19 pandemic, proving the resilience of our business model. The chart below provides a breakdown of our revenue by geographic segment for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023. We address multiple customer end markets, which also contributes to our resilience in reducing the impact of volatility of external factors such as market conditions and macroeconomic developments. We have positioned ourselves as a leading generalist equipment rental company that is also active in the attractive specialist sub-segment and in DIY, with specialist rental and DIY representing 28% of our revenue for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023. For the year ended December 31, 2022, approximately 54% of our sales were derived from non-construction end-markets, indicating a relatively modest exposure to the cyclical construction market. Furthermore, our exposure to the construction end market includes a large part of less cyclical phases of construction activities, such as the fit out, maintenance and operational phases. The chart below provides a breakdown of our revenue by end markets for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023. ----- Over time, we have continued developing our expertise in specialist rental equipment, focusing on nonconstruction related end-markets, such as site preparation, modular space, measurement, testing and safety, sanitation, portable kitchen, hoisting and lifting, access control, and industrial rental and pumps. We believe our specialized knowledge is key to our ability to service different niche markets, providing further resilience and less exposure to the more cyclical construction market. By leveraging our generalist rental equipment business, we also aim to provide the best and most comprehensive rental solutions for our customers with the objective of cross-selling our specialist equipment to fuel future growth. Ultimately, our specialist business represents a key peer differentiator with customers, which we believe provides for higher returns. In parallel, we also operate in the niche market of DIY rental, with more than 3,100 DIY shop-in-shops as at June 30, 2023, where customers at DIY retail stores have access to primarily smaller equipment rental such as tools. This type of business is less cyclical than traditional equipment rental market and the costs to operate this business are typically lower than other equipment rental businesses due to the strong operational leverage of the existing rental depot network. In the DIY market, we are able to offer convenience as a differentiating factor to our customers, generating higher customer foot traffic in the stores, at a time when e-commerce is putting a strain on retailers and brick-and-mortar stores. We strive to offer a wide range of equipment and tools across all the phases of construction projects, including the build (both heavy construction and fit out), operate and maintain phases. Our business model also hinges on providing a diversified range of products to our customers. We particularly focus on smaller equipment rentals, such as perforators, ladders, scaffolding, power saws, power generators, sanding equipment, which represented approximately 48% of our rental revenue for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023. These rentals position us within the less-cyclical 'fit out', 'maintain' and 'operate' phases of the asset cycle, as demand for such rentals is typically more resilient and makes us less dependent on lengthy construction projects. For example, smaller equipment rentals tend to be more sought after for renovation and maintenance use, which are inherently less exposed to cyclical demand than other end uses. As of June 30, 2023, with a fleet of approximately 860,000 equipment units, ranging from providing generalist tools to more specialized equipment, in addition to value-added services such as logistics, we aim to provide full turnkey solutions to strengthen our customer relationships and remain our customers' preferred rental partner. Furthermore, with a comprehensive network of 759 depots (strategically located within a 50-kilometer reach of our key customers and project sites across Europe) and more than 3,100 DIY shop-in-shops across Europe as of June 30, 2023, we are capable of mobilizing our rental fleet even in remote places for any customer or user at the right time, through multiple delivery methods: pick up and return or delivery to desired locations. By constantly adapting our network to changes and fluctuations in the market, we have the strategic ability to open or close access points near our customers. Based on market trends or developments in specific regions in Europe, we can adapt swiftly and embrace changes in our industry. Our hub-and-spoke networking model provides a diversified customer reach and develops efficiency and flexibility in our operations, ensuring that we are close to our customers and their projects, whether for pick-up and return or project delivery. This proximity to our customers results in shorter transport times, lower costs and lower CO2 emissions. Supported by our broad product offering and dense network, we also benefit from a large and diversified customer base, serving numerous customers of different sizes and from different sectors through our various channels (both generalist and specialist rental products) ranging from DIY customers, cash customers and craftsmen to large industrial, services and construction companies, potentially operating in different economic cycles. For the year ended December 31, 2022, our top 10 customers accounted for 7.4% of our revenue, with no single customer representing more than 2% of our revenue. We benefit from strong customer loyalty, evidenced by the fact that our 10 largest customers by revenue have, on average, an approximately 20-year relationship with us. -----

Subsubsection Title: Well-invested fleet focused on smaller equipment with strong unit economics and robust fleet management and digital capabilities
Subsubsection Text: We differentiate our offering from most of our peers by focusing on smaller rental items, such as tools and access equipment, in addition to construction equipment and containers. The chart below shows our revenue breakdown by product category for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023. Over the last five years, we have invested more than €1.4 billion to renew our rental fleet, with €448 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. We have a young, well-invested fleet with a historical purchase value of approximately €2.8 billion as of June 30, 2023. These investments have reduced the weighted average age of our fleet to 53 months as of June 30, 2023, allowing us to offer our customers the latest advanced equipment and sufficient headroom to reduce or delay our capital expenditures during economic downturns. The chart below shows our rental equipment fleet's average useful life and its age (in months), by product category, as of June 30, 2023. Our tools product category, which amounted to 16% of our rental sales for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023, has the lowest spread between average useful life and average fleet age in our fleet, with an average of approximately 3.5 years of use remaining before ultimately needing to be replaced. Our smaller equipment, such as perforators, ladders, scaffolding, power saws, power generators, sanding equipment, and other small tools, are characterized by superior unit economics compared to our other product categories, as they lead to higher money utilization rates (defined as our twelve-month fleet sales divided by the historical purchase price, based on the weighted average price by number of rental units). For the year ended December 31, 2022, our money utilization rate for the tools and light equipment product category was higher than our larger product categories, such as construction equipment, which we believe results in an increase in our return on fleet investments and an increase in our resilience through business cycles, given our high exposure to the tools and light equipment category. The chart below shows our money utilization rate for our different types of rental equipment for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023. ----- Our focus on tools and access equipment makes us less dependent on lengthy construction projects and more exposed to the less cyclical renovation market, where we have a better pricing power among our smaller customers. On our major long-term projects, we often provide a full range of equipment from small hand-held tools to larger equipment, reflecting our ability to support our clients on their various steps and needs with adequate and available equipment. This ability to provide full range of equipment in due time ultimately fosters relationships with our clients, creating recurring revenue streams and the potential for cross-selling between our generalist and specialist equipment. We have developed a robust asset management strategy for our extensive fleet. Our fleet management strategy covers the entire lifecycle of our equipment units, which includes purchasing, renting, and equipment servicing, as well as reselling the equipment at the end of its financial or economic lifetime. When making purchasing decisions, we seek to provide a true one-stop shop experience for our customers by ensuring a high degree of availability across our entire rental range and equipment that is adapted to their needs. By closely monitoring trends, events and market prices, we can quickly adjust and adapt our offer to customers' needs. For example, the share of Eco-labelled equipment in our fleet is relatively high and growing in line with higher market demand for electrical, hybrid or battery-powered equipment and the highest sustainability standards. Simultaneously, we seek time- and cost-efficiency to maximize our economies of scale and fleet occupancy performance. These initiatives improve our fleet availability and utilization rates while minimizing our maintenance capital expenditures. We have implemented an advanced and integrated infrastructure to drive decision making for our fleet, such as enterprise resource planning and specialized hardware and software. This asset management system allows us to track the complete life cycle of any rental asset in our fleet, providing us with visibility on our any given item (such as depot performance, inventory levels, fleet allocation and pricing) and the ability to adjust our fleet investment and pricing. This enables us able to serve our customers according to their needs, quickly and efficiently. In addition, this system makes it possible to limit downtime and improve utilization rates and pricing. Finally, as a piece of our equipment reaches the end of its lifecycle within the Company, we believe that we are able to optimize the timing of its resale and maximize its resale value through closely following secondary market prices and trends and taking third-party insights into account. Our fleet management strategy also relies on a central procurement strategy. This enables us to benefit from economies of scale and allows us to be close to our OEMs and their product development, positioning us at the forefront for the latest products in terms of efficiency, safety and sustainability. In addition, our relationships with OEMs not only allows us to negotiate better prices, but it also give us insights on the availability issues that may occur due to shortages of materials. In 2022, the equipment markets suffered from supply chain shortages. Due to our excellent relationships with our OEMs, we were able to successfully navigate these shortages, which we believe differentiates us from our competitors. We also foster our relationships with our OEMs by collaborating on technological developments and data analyses, and we aim to deepen our cooperation with them further. In addition, we have invested and continue to invest in the latest technology to help us efficiently process our fleet maintenance and repairs and minimize our related costs and administrative workload. These technological capabilities allow us to be in full control of depreciation and replacement strategies and therefore systematically improve our fleet usage, composition and performance. We monitor and reduce the impact machine repairs and maintenance have on lifetime costs and resale value. Finally, we seek to be a leader in innovation and digital transformation across the entire rental process, which we believe results in higher customer satisfaction and percentage of recurring business, better fleet damage control and substantial emissions savings. We were an early adopter of digital offerings in the European rental market, having anticipated this trend by preparing a detailed mapping of our customer experiences per segment, with the aim to simplify online rental in all our customer's life cycle stages and provide a one-stop-shop solution: from becoming a customer to online renting, logistics, usage, having all relevant information available and invoicing. In parallel, this digital transformation generates operational efficiencies by allowing us to optimize our processes such as transport and logistics. -----

Subsubsection Title: Strong financial and operational track record supported by counter-cyclical cash generation through capital expenditure flexibility and proven M&A integration capabilities
Subsubsection Text: Our financial performance has been driven by a strategic combination of strong organic growth and the successful integration of both transformative and smaller bolt-on acquisitions, which have expanded our geographical reach and product offering.
